007import com.badlogic.gdx.math.Frustum;

009import com.badlogic.gdx.scenes.scene2d.Action;
010import com.badlogic.gdx.scenes.scene2d.Actor;
011import com.badlogic.gdx.scenes.scene2d.Stage;
012import com.badlogic.gdx.scenes.scene2d.actions.Actions;
013import com.badlogic.gdx.scenes.scene2d.actions.TemporalAction;
014import com.badlogic.gdx.utils.Align;
015import com.badlogic.gdx.utils.IntIntMap;
016import com.badlogic.gdx.utils.viewport.Viewport;
017import squidpony.ArrayTools;
018import squidpony.IColorCenter;
019import squidpony.panel.IColoredString;
020import squidpony.panel.ISquidPanel;
021import squidpony.squidgrid.Direction;
022import squidpony.squidgrid.Radius;

028import java.util.ArrayList;
029
030/**
031 * A general-purpose char display grid that supports one layer of backgrounds and arbitrarily many layers of foreground,
032 * only rendering foreground chars when something is present at a char's location. This also stores an ArrayList of
033 * {@link TextCellFactory.Glyph} items that can be added to using {@link #glyph(char, Color, int, int)} or one of
034 * several other methods; these Glyphs can have effects performed on them that are analogous to the effects on
035 * {@link SquidPanel}'s {@link AnimatedEntity} effects, such as
036 * {@link #slide(TextCellFactory.Glyph, int, int, int, int, float, Runnable)}. Unlike SquidPanel and SquidLayers, this
037 * class does not typically provide many overloads for each method, and usually limits the overloads to one that takes
038 * a packed float color and one that takes a libGDX {@link Color}, and all the other parameters are expected to be
039 * specified explicitly rather than relying on default behavior. SparseLayers tends to perform better than SquidLayers,
040 * especially when a lot of the map is unassigned/blank. It will cause less GC pressure when packed floats are used, and
041 * because {@link SColor} constants pre-calculate their packed float values, using the overloads that take a Color will
042 * perform a little better when given an SColor than a plain libGDX Color. This class makes heavy use of
043 * {@link SColor#lerpFloatColors(float, float, float)} because it should cause no GC pressure (it doesn't create
044 * temporary Color objects), and if you don't want to mutate Colors in-place (which is a bad idea for constants), then
045 * using lerpFloatColors with the packed float color API here should be very effective.
046 * <br>
047 * The names are a little different for some member fields here; there's a {@link TextCellFactory} called {@link #font},
048 * a {@code float[][]} called {@link #backgrounds} that stores packed float colors, an ArrayList of
049 * {@link SparseTextMap} that implements the sparse drawing behavior of foreground chars called {@link #layers}, and so
050 * on.
051 * <br>
052 * Created by Tommy Ettinger on 7/28/2017.
053 */
054public class SparseLayers extends Actor implements IPackedColorPanel {
055    public int gridWidth, gridHeight;
056    /**
057     * A 2D float array of background colors as packed floats. Must have dimensions matching {@link #gridWidth} and
058     * {@link #gridHeight}, and must be non-null with non-null interior arrays, but can otherwise be assigned 2D float
059     * arrays from other sources (that use floats to represent colors, not just any number).
060     */
061    public float[][] backgrounds;
062    /**
063     * The default foreground color when none is specified, as a Color object. Defaults to white.
064     */
065    public Color defaultForeground = SColor.WHITE,
066    /**
067     * Currently unused internally, but public so if some background color needs to be stored with this SparseLayers,
068     * then there will be a logical place for it. Defaults to black.
069     */
070            defaultBackground = SColor.BLACK;
071    /**
072     * The value of {@link #defaultForeground} as a float, for easier usage with the methods that use floats for colors.
073     * Defaults to white.
074     */
075    public float defaultPackedForeground = SColor.FLOAT_WHITE,
076    /**
077     * The value of {@link #defaultBackground} as a float, for easier usage with the methods that use floats for colors.
078     * Currently unused internally, but public so if some background color needs to be stored with this SparseLayers,
079     * then there will be a logical place for it. Defaults to black.
080     */
081            defaultPackedBackground = SColor.FLOAT_BLACK;
082    /**
083     * A list of SparseTextMap objects, with each representing a foreground layer.
084     */
085    public ArrayList<SparseTextMap> layers;
086    protected IntIntMap mapping;
087    /**
088     * The TextCellFactory that is used to determine font size as well as cell size; must be initialized, usually using
089     * {@link TextCellFactory#initBySize()}, if this is changed after construction.
090     */
091    public TextCellFactory font;
092    /**
093     * Will always be 0 unless user code affects it; use {@link #hasActiveAnimations()} to track animations instead.
094     * The approach of tracking animations via a counter was prone to error when multiple effects might remove a Glyph
095     * or adjust the animationCount in one direction but not the other. This could result in never-ending phases of a
096     * game where input wasn't handled because animationCount was greater than 0, but whatever effect was supposed to
097     * reduce animationCount would never happen.
098     * @deprecated Use {@link #hasActiveAnimations()} instead of adjusting this manually
099     */
100    public int animationCount = 0;
101    /**
102     * A list of individually-movable Glyph objects. This field is public, and though it shouldn't be assigned null (you
103     * don't really need to be told that), there may be cases where you may need manual control over what Glyph objects
104     * should be added or removed from this SparseLayers.
105     */
106    public ArrayList<TextCellFactory.Glyph> glyphs;
107    /**
108     * An IColorCenter to affect color caching and filtering; usually a SquidColorCenter, which can be easily obtained
109     * via {@link DefaultResources#getSCC()}.
110     */
111    public IColorCenter<Color> scc;
112
113    protected SparseLayers()
114    {
115    }
116    public SparseLayers(int gridWidth, int gridHeight)
117    {
118        this(gridWidth, gridHeight, 10, 16, DefaultResources.getStretchableFont());
119    }
120
121    public SparseLayers(int gridWidth, int gridHeight, float cellWidth, float cellHeight)
122    {
123        this(gridWidth, gridHeight, cellWidth, cellHeight, DefaultResources.getStretchableFont());
124    }
125
126    public SparseLayers(int gridWidth, int gridHeight, float cellWidth, float cellHeight, TextCellFactory font) {
127        this(gridWidth, gridHeight, cellWidth, cellHeight, font, 0f, 0f);
128    }
129
130    public SparseLayers(int gridWidth, int gridHeight, float cellWidth, float cellHeight, TextCellFactory font, float xOffset, float yOffset) {
131        this.gridWidth = MathUtils.clamp(gridWidth, 1, 65535);
132        this.gridHeight = MathUtils.clamp(gridHeight, 1, 65535);
133        backgrounds = new float[this.gridWidth][this.gridHeight];
134        layers = new ArrayList<>(4);
135        if(font.initialized())
136            this.font = font;
137        else
138            this.font = font.width(cellWidth).height(cellHeight).initBySize();
139        layers.add(new SparseTextMap(gridWidth * gridHeight >> 2));
140        mapping = new IntIntMap(4);
141        mapping.put(0, 0);
142        glyphs = new ArrayList<>(16);
143        scc = DefaultResources.getSCC();
144        setBounds(xOffset, yOffset,
145                this.font.actualCellWidth * this.gridWidth, this.font.actualCellHeight * this.gridHeight);
146    }
147
148    /**
149     * Gets the number of layers currently used in this SparseLayers; if a layer is put into that is equal to or greater
150     * than this layer count, then a new layer is created to hold the latest placement. It is recommended that you
151     * assign to the layer equal to the result of this method if you want to add a layer. You can add to layers that are
152     * higher than this result, and can technically do so out of order, but this just gets confusing because their
153     * ordering won't be related to the numbers of the layers.
154     * @return the current number of layers in this SparseLayers
155     */
156    public int getLayerCount()
157    {
158        return layers.size();
159    }
160
161    /**
162     * Gets the layer, as a SparseTextMap, that is associated with the given int. If none is associated, this returns
163     * null. The associating number does not necessarily have to be less than the number of layers in this SparseLayers.
164     * Returns a direct reference to the SparseTextMap layer.
165     * @param layer the int that is associated with a layer, usually the int used to add to that layer.
166     * @return the SparseTextMap layer associated with the given int
167     */
168    public SparseTextMap getLayer(int layer)
169    {
170        layer = mapping.get(layer, -1);
171        if(layer < 0)
172            return null;
173        else
174            return layers.get(layer);
175    }
176
177    /**
178     * Sets the SparseTextMap associated with the given layerNumber to the given contents. If layerNumber is too high
179     * to set an existing layer, this will add contents as a new layer on top of the others.
180     * @param layerNumber must be 0 or greater
181     * @param contents a SparseTextMap, possibly obtained with {@link #getLayer(int)}
182     */
183    public void setLayer(int layerNumber, SparseTextMap contents)
184    {
185        if(layerNumber < 0)
186            return;
187        layerNumber = mapping.get(layerNumber, layerNumber);
188        if(layerNumber >= layers.size())
189        {
190            mapping.put(layerNumber, layers.size());
191            layers.add(contents);
192        }
193        else
194        {
195            layers.set(layerNumber, contents);
196        }
197
198    }
199
200    /**
201     * Finds the layer number associated with layerMap, or -1 if the given SparseTextMap is not in this SparseLayers.
202     * @param layerMap a SparseTextMap that was likely returned by {@link #addLayer()}
203     * @return the int the layer is associated with, or -1 if it is not in this SparseLayers.
204     */
205    public int findLayer(SparseTextMap layerMap)
206    {
207        int a = layers.indexOf(layerMap);
208        if(a < 0)
209            return -1;
210        return mapping.findKey(a, -1);
211    }
212
213    /**
214     * Adds a layer as a SparseTextMap to this SparseLayers and returns the one just added. The layer will generally be
215     * associated with a layer number equal to the number of layers currently present, and will be rendered over the
216     * existing layers. It might not be associated with the same number if layers were added out-of-order or with skips
217     * between associations. If you want to add a layer at some alternate layer number (which can be confusing but may
218     * be needed for some reason), there is another overload that allows you to specify the association number.
219     * If you may have added some layers out of order or skipped some numbers, you can use
220     * {@link #findLayer(SparseTextMap)} on the returned SparseTextMap to get its association number.
221     * @return a SparseTextMap that was just added; null if something went wrong
222     */
223    public SparseTextMap addLayer()
224    {
225        int association = layers.size();
226        while (mapping.containsKey(association)) {
227            ++association;
228        }
229        return addLayer(association);
230    }
231    /**
232     * Adds a layer as a SparseTextMap to this SparseLayers and returns the one just added, or returns an existing layer
233     * if one is already associated with the given number. The layer can be greater than the number of layers currently
234     * present, which will add a layer to be rendered over the existing layers, but the number that refers to that layer
235     * will not change. It is recommended that to add a layer, you only add at the value equal to
236     * {@link #getLayerCount()}, which will maintain the order and layer numbers in a sane way, and this is the behavior
237     * of the addLayer overload that does not take a parameter.
238     * @param association the number to associate the layer with; should usually be between 0 and {@link #getLayerCount()} inclusive
239     * @return a SparseTextMap that either was just added or was already associated with the given layer number; null if something went wrong
240     */
241    public SparseTextMap addLayer(int association)
242    {
243        if(association < 0)
244            return null;
245        association = mapping.get(association, association);
246        if(association >= layers.size())
247        {
248            mapping.put(association, layers.size());
249            SparseTextMap stm = new SparseTextMap(gridWidth * gridHeight >> 4);
250            layers.add(stm);
251            return stm;
252        }
253        else
254        {
255            return layers.get(association);
256        }
257    }
258
259    /**
260     * Puts the character {@code c} at {@code (x, y)} with the default foreground. Does not change the background.
261     *
262     * @param x the x position to place the char at
263     * @param y the y position to place the char at
264     * @param c the char to place, using the default foreground color
265     */
266    @Override
267    public void put(int x, int y, char c) {
268        put(x, y, c, defaultPackedForeground, 0f);
269    }
270
271    /**
272     * Puts the ICellVisible cell at the position x,y; does not change the background. If {@code cell.getPackedColor()}
273     * is 0f, then this does not change the foreground contents either. Does not filter the given colors.
274     * @param x the x position to place the char at
275     * @param y the y position to place the char at
276     * @param cell an ICellVisible, which is often implemented outside of SquidLib; this uses its char and color.
277     */
278    public void put(int x, int y, ICellVisible cell) {
279        put(x, y, cell.getSymbol(), cell.getPackedColor(), 0f);
280    }
281
282    /**
283     * Puts the given string horizontally with the first character at the given
284     * offset. Uses the given color for the text and does not change the background
285     * color at all.
286     * <p>
287     * Does not word wrap. Characters that are not renderable (due to being at
288     * negative offsets or offsets greater than the grid size) will not be shown
289     * but will not cause any malfunctions.
290     *
291     * @param xOffset    the x coordinate of the first character
292     * @param yOffset    the y coordinate of the first character
293     * @param string     the characters to be displayed
294     * @param foreground the color to use for the text
295     */
296    @Override
297    public void put(int xOffset, int yOffset, String string, Color foreground) {
298        put(xOffset, yOffset, string, foreground, null);
299    }
300
301    /**
302     * Puts the given string horizontally with the first character at the given
303     * offset, using the colors that {@code cs} provides. Does not change the
304     * background colors. Does filter the colors from cs if the color center this
305     * uses is set up to filter colors.
306     * <p>
307     * Does not word wrap. Characters that are not renderable (due to being at
308     * negative offsets or offsets greater than the grid size) will not be shown
309     * but will not cause any malfunctions.
310     *
311     * @param xOffset the x coordinate of the first character
312     * @param yOffset the y coordinate of the first character
313     * @param cs an {@link IColoredString} with potentially multiple colors
314     */
315    @Override
316    public void put(int xOffset, int yOffset, IColoredString<? extends Color> cs) {
317        int x = xOffset;
318        for (IColoredString.Bucket<? extends Color> fragment : cs) {
319            final String s = fragment.getText();
320            final Color color = fragment.getColor();
321            put(x, yOffset, s, color == null ? getDefaultForegroundColor() : scc.filter(color), null);
322            x += s.length();
323        }
324    }
325
326    /**
327     * Puts the character {@code c} at {@code (x, y)} with some {@code color}.
328     * Does not change the background colors.
329     *
330     * @param x the x position to place the char at
331     * @param y the y position to place the char at
332     * @param c the char to place
333     * @param color the color to use for c; if null or fully transparent, nothing will change in the foreground
334     */
335    @Override
336    public void put(int x, int y, char c, Color color) {
337        put(x, y, c, color, null);
338    }
339
340    /**
341     * Sets the background colors to match the given Color 2D array. If the colors argument is null, does nothing.
342     * This will filter each Color in colors if the color center this uses has a filter.
343     * @param colors the background colors for the given chars
344     */
345    public void put(Color[][] colors)
346    {
347        put(null, colors);
348    }
349
350    /**
351     * Sets the background colors to match the given 2D array of colors as packed floats. If the colors argument is
352     * null, does nothing. This will not filter the passed colors at all.
353     * @param colors the background colors to use for this SparseLayers
354     */
355    public void put(float[][] colors)
356    {
357        put(null, colors);
358    }
359    /**
360     * Places the given char 2D array, if-non-null, in the default foreground color starting at x=0, y=0.
361     * @param chars a 2D char array to place without affecting background colors; these chars will use the default foreground color
362     */
363    public void putChars(char[][] chars) {
364        if(chars == null)
365            return;
366        SparseTextMap layer = layers.get(0);
367        for (int i = 0; i < chars.length; i++) {
368            if (chars[i] != null) {
369                for (int j = 0; j < chars[i].length; j++) {
370                    layer.place(i, j, chars[i][j], defaultPackedForeground);
371                }
372            }
373        }
374    }
375    /**
376     * Places the given char 2D array, if-non-null, in the foreground starting at x=0, y=0. Each char will be drawn in 
377     * the corresponding foreground color from foregrounds.
378     * @param chars a 2D char array to place without affecting background colors
379     * @param foregrounds a 2D float array of encoded colors as produced by {@link Color#toFloatBits()}; applies to char foregrounds
380     */
381    public void putChars(char[][] chars, float[][] foregrounds) {
382        if(chars == null)
383            return;
384        if(foregrounds == null)
385        {
386            putChars(chars);
387            return;
388        }
389        SparseTextMap layer = layers.get(0);
390        for (int i = 0; i < chars.length; i++) {
391            if (chars[i] != null) {
392                for (int j = 0; j < chars[i].length; j++) {
393                    layer.place(i, j, chars[i][j], foregrounds[i][j]);
394                }
395            }
396        }
397    }
398    /**
399     * Places the given char 2D array, if-non-null, in the foreground starting at x=0, y=0. Each char will be drawn in 
400     * the corresponding foreground color from foregrounds.
401     * @param chars a 2D char array to place without affecting background colors
402     * @param foregrounds a 2D array of libGDX colors (any may also be an SColor or other subclass); applies to char foregrounds
403     */
404    public void putChars(char[][] chars, Color[][] foregrounds) {
405        if(chars == null)
406            return;
407        if(foregrounds == null)
408        {
409            putChars(chars);
410            return;
411        }
412        SparseTextMap layer = layers.get(0);
413        for (int i = 0; i < chars.length; i++) {
414            if (chars[i] != null) {
415                for (int j = 0; j < chars[i].length; j++) {
416                    layer.place(i, j, chars[i][j], scc.filter(foregrounds[i][j]).toFloatBits());
417                }
418            }
419        }
420    }
421    /**
422     * Places the given char 2D array, if-non-null, in the default foreground color starting at x=0, y=0, while also
423     * setting the background colors to match the given Color 2D array. If the colors argument is null, does nothing. If
424     * the chars argument is null, only affects the background colors. This will filter each Color in colors if the
425     * color center this uses has a filter.
426     * @param chars Can be {@code null}, indicating that only colors must be put.
427     * @param colors the background colors for the given chars
428     */
429    @Override
430    public void put(char[][] chars, Color[][] colors) {
431        if(chars == null)
432        {
433            if(colors != null)
434            {
435                for (int i = 0; i < colors.length; i++) {
436                    if (colors[i] == null)
437                        continue;
438                    for (int j = 0; j < colors[i].length; j++) {
439                        backgrounds[i][j] = (colors[i][j] == null) ? 0f : scc.filter(colors[i][j]).toFloatBits();
440                    }
441                }
442            }
443        }
444        else
445        {
446            SparseTextMap layer = layers.get(0);
447            if(colors == null)
448            {
449                for (int i = 0; i < chars.length; i++) {
450                    if(chars[i] == null)
451                        continue;
452                    for (int j = 0; j < chars[i].length; j++) {
453                        layer.place(i, j, chars[i][j], defaultPackedForeground);
454                    }
455                }
456            }
457            else
458            {
459                for (int i = 0; i < chars.length && i < colors.length; i++) {
460                    if(colors[i] == null || chars[i] == null)
461                        continue;
462                    for (int j = 0; j < chars[i].length && j < colors[i].length; j++) {
463                        if(colors[i][j] == null)
464                            layer.place(i, j, chars[i][j], defaultPackedForeground);
465                        else
466                            put(i, j, chars[i][j], defaultPackedForeground, scc.filter(colors[i][j]).toFloatBits());
467                    }
468                }
469            }
470        }
471    }
472    /**
473     * Places the given char 2D array, if-non-null, in the default foreground color starting at x=0, y=0, while also
474     * setting the background colors to match the given 2D array of colors as packed floats. If the colors argument is
475     * null, does nothing. If the chars argument is null, only affects the background colors. This will not filter the
476     * passed colors at all.
477     * @param chars Can be {@code null}, indicating that only colors must be put.
478     * @param colors the background colors for the given chars
479     */
480    public void put(char[][] chars, float[][] colors) {
481        if(chars == null)
482        {
483            if(colors != null) {
484                for (int i = 0; i < colors.length; i++) {
485                    if (colors[i] == null)
486                        continue;
487                    System.arraycopy(colors[i], 0, backgrounds[i], 0, colors[i].length);
488                }
489            }
490        }
491        else
492        {
493            if(colors == null)
494            {
495                for (int i = 0; i < chars.length; i++) {
496                    if(chars[i] == null)
497                        continue;
498                    for (int j = 0; j < chars[i].length; j++) {
499                        put(i, j, chars[i][j], defaultPackedForeground, 0f);
500                    }
501                }
502            }
503            else
504            {
505                for (int i = 0; i < chars.length && i < colors.length; i++) {
506                    if(colors[i] == null || chars[i] == null)
507                        continue;
508                    for (int j = 0; j < chars[i].length && j < colors[i].length; j++) {
509                        put(i, j, chars[i][j], defaultPackedForeground, colors[i][j]);
510                    }
511                }
512            }
513        }
514    }
515    /**
516     * Places the given char 2D array, if-non-null, with the given foreground colors in the first Color 2D array,
517     * starting at x=0, y=0, while also setting the background colors to match the second Color 2D array. If the
518     * bgColors argument is null, only affects foreground chars and colors. If the chars argument or the fgColors
519     * argument is null, only affects the background colors. Any positions where a Color in fgColors is null will not
520     * have a char placed (this can be used to restrict what is placed). This will filter each Color in the background
521     * and foreground if the color center this uses has a filter.
522     * @param chars Can be {@code null}, indicating that only colors must be put.
523     * @param fgColors the foreground Colors for the given chars
524     * @param bgColors the background Colors for the given chars
525     */
526    public void put(char[][] chars, Color[][] fgColors, Color[][] bgColors) {
527        if(chars == null || fgColors == null)
528        {
529            if(bgColors != null)
530            {
531                for (int i = 0; i < bgColors.length; i++) {
532                    if (bgColors[i] == null)
533                        continue;
534                    for (int j = 0; j < bgColors[i].length; j++) {
535                        backgrounds[i][j] = (bgColors[i][j] == null) ? 0f : scc.filter(bgColors[i][j]).toFloatBits();
536                    }
537                }
538            }
539        }
540        else
541        {
542            if(bgColors == null)
543            {
544                for (int i = 0; i < chars.length && i < fgColors.length; i++) {
545                    if(chars[i] == null || fgColors[i] == null)
546                        continue;
547                    for (int j = 0; j < chars[i].length && j < fgColors[i].length; j++) {
548                        put(i, j, chars[i][j], fgColors[i][j], null);
549                    }
550                }
551            }
552            else
553            {
554                for (int i = 0; i < chars.length && i < bgColors.length && i < fgColors.length; i++) {
555                    if(bgColors[i] == null || chars[i] == null || fgColors[i] == null)
556                        continue;
557                    for (int j = 0; j < chars[i].length && j < bgColors[i].length && j < fgColors[i].length; j++) {                         
558                        put(i, j, chars[i][j], fgColors[i][j], bgColors[i][j]);
559                    }
560                }
561            }
562        }
563    }
564    /**
565     * Places the given char 2D array, if-non-null, with the given foreground colors in the first float 2D array,
566     * starting at x=0, y=0, while also setting the background colors to match the second float 2D array. If the
567     * bgColors argument is null, only affects foreground chars and colors. If the chars argument or the fgColors
568     * argument is null, only affects the background colors. Any positions where a float in fgColors is 0 will not
569     * have a char placed (this can be used to restrict what is placed). This will not filter any colors.
570     * @param chars Can be {@code null}, indicating that only colors must be put.
571     * @param fgColors the foreground colors for the given chars, as packed floats
572     * @param bgColors the background colors for the given chars, as packed floats
573     */
574    public void put(char[][] chars, float[][] fgColors, float[][] bgColors) {
575        if(chars == null || fgColors == null)
576        {
577            if(bgColors != null)
578            {
579                for (int i = 0; i < bgColors.length; i++) {
580                    if (bgColors[i] == null)
581                        continue;
582                    System.arraycopy(bgColors[i], 0, backgrounds[i], 0, bgColors[i].length);
583                }
584            }
585        }
586        else
587        {
588            if(bgColors == null)
589            {
590                for (int i = 0; i < chars.length && i < fgColors.length; i++) {
591                    if(chars[i] == null || fgColors[i] == null)
592                        continue;
593                    for (int j = 0; j < chars[i].length && j < fgColors[i].length; j++) {
594                        put(i, j, chars[i][j], fgColors[i][j], 0f);
595                    }
596                }
597            }
598            else
599            {
600                for (int i = 0; i < chars.length && i < bgColors.length && i < fgColors.length; i++) {
601                    if(bgColors[i] == null || chars[i] == null || fgColors[i] == null)
602                        continue;
603                    for (int j = 0; j < chars[i].length && j < bgColors[i].length && j < fgColors[i].length; j++) {
604                        put(i, j, chars[i][j], fgColors[i][j], bgColors[i][j]);
605                    }
606                }
607            }
608        }
609    }
610
611    /**
612     * @return The number of cells that this panel spans, horizontally.
613     */
614    @Override
615    public int gridWidth() {
616        return gridWidth;
617    }
618
619    /**
620     * @return The number of cells that this panel spans, vertically.
621     */
622    @Override
623    public int gridHeight() {
624        return gridHeight;
625    }

627    /**
628     * The same as {@link #gridWidth()}; here for compatibility with SquidPanel.
629     * @return The number of cells that this panel spans, horizontally.
630     */
631    public int getGridWidth() {
632        return gridWidth;
633    }
634
635    /**
636     * The same as {@link #gridHeight()}; here for compatibility with SquidPanel.
637     * @return The number of cells that this panel spans, vertically.
638     */
639    public int getGridHeight() {
640        return gridHeight;
641    }

643    /**
644     * @return The width of a cell, in number of pixels.
645     */
646    @Override
647    public int cellWidth() {
648        return Math.round(font.actualCellWidth);
649    }
650
651    /**
652     * @return The height of a cell, in number of pixels.
653     */
654    @Override
655    public int cellHeight() {
656        return Math.round(font.actualCellHeight);
657    }

659    /**
660     * Changes the width and height of chars the font renders, inside the same cell size.
661     * Primarily useful if the font has issues and doesn't line up visually; some older versions of .fnt files
662     * distributed with SquidLib had this type of problem (and some may still).
663     * Provides compatibility with SquidPanel code.
664     * @param wide width in approximate pixels
665     * @param high height in approximate pixels
666     * @return this for chaining.
667     */
668    public SparseLayers setTextSize(float wide, float high)
669    {
670        font.tweakWidth(wide).tweakHeight(high).initBySize();
671        return this;
672    }
673    /**
674     * Sets the default foreground color.
675     * This Color can be null, which will
676     * usually not be rendered unless a different color is specified.
677     * @param color a libGDX Color object or an extension of Color, such as SColor
678     */
679    @Override
680    public void setDefaultForeground(Color color) {
681        defaultForeground = color;
682        if(color != null)
683            defaultPackedForeground = color.toFloatBits();
684        else
685            defaultPackedForeground = 0f;
686    }
687    /**
688     * @return The default foreground color (if none was set with
689     * {@link #setDefaultForeground(Color)}), or the last color set with
690     * {@link #setDefaultForeground(Color)}. This Color can be null which
691     * will usually not be rendered unless a different color is specified.
692     */
693    @Override
694    public Color getDefaultForegroundColor() {
695        return defaultForeground;
696    }
697
698    /**
699     * Sets the default background color.
700     * This Color can be null, which will
701     * usually not be rendered unless a different color is specified.
702     * @param color a libGDX Color object or an extension of Color, such as SColor
703     */
704    public void setDefaultBackground(Color color) {
705        defaultBackground = color;
706        if(color != null)
707            defaultPackedBackground = color.toFloatBits();
708        else
709            defaultPackedBackground = 0f;
710    }
711    /**
712     * @return The default background color (if none was set with
713     * {@link #setDefaultBackground(Color)}), or the last color set
714     * with {@link #setDefaultBackground(Color)}. This can be null,
715     * which will usually not be rendered unless a different color
716     * is specified.
717     */
718    public Color getDefaultBackgroundColor() {
719        return defaultBackground;
720    }

722    /**
723     * Method to change the backing {@link IColorCenter}.
724     * Note that the IColorCenter is not used to filter floats that encode colors, so passing the result of
725     * {@link Color#toFloatBits()} can be used to bypass the filtering if you want a color to be used exactly.
726     * @param icc an IColorCenter that can cache and possibly filter {@link Color} objects
727     * @return {@code this} for chaining
728     */
729    @Override
730    public ISquidPanel<Color> setColorCenter(IColorCenter<Color> icc) {
731        scc = icc;
732        return this;
733    }
734
735    /**
736     * Gets the IColorCenter this can use to filter Color objects; this is usually a {@link SquidColorCenter}.
737     * Note that the IColorCenter is not used to filter floats that encode colors, so passing the result of
738     * {@link Color#toFloatBits()} can be used to bypass the filtering if you want a color to be used exactly.
739     * @return the IColorCenter this uses
740     */
741    public IColorCenter<Color> getColorCenter() {
742        return scc;
743    }

745    /**
746     * @return The panel doing the real job, i.e. an instance of
747     * {@code SquidPanel}. The type of colors is unspecified, as some
748     * clients have forwarding instances of this class that hides that
749     * the type of color of the backer differs from the type of color in
750     * {@code this}.
751     * <p>
752     * This implementation returns {@code this}.
753     */
754    @Override
755    public ISquidPanel<?> getBacker() {
756        return this;
757    }
758
759    /**
760     * Puts the char c at the position x,y with the given foreground and background colors. If foreground is null or is
761     * fully transparent (all channels 0), then this does not change the foreground contents.
762     * If background is null or is fully transparent, this does not change the background. Uses the color center to
763     * potentially filter the given colors; this can be changed with {@link #setColorCenter(IColorCenter)}.
764     * @param x the x position to place the char at
765     * @param y the y position to place the char at
766     * @param c the char to place
767     * @param foreground the color to use for c; if null or fully transparent, nothing will change in the foreground
768     * @param background the color to use for the cell; if null or fully transparent, nothing will change in the background
769     */
770    public void put(int x, int y, char c, Color foreground, Color background)
771    {
772        put(x, y, c, foreground == null ? 0f : scc.filter(foreground).toFloatBits(),
773                background == null ? 0f : scc.filter(background).toFloatBits());
774    }
775    /**
776     * Puts the ICellVisible cell at the position x,y with the given background color as an encoded float, such as
777     * those produced by {@link Color#toFloatBits()}. If {@code cell.getPackedColor()} is 0f, then this does not
778     * change the foreground contents. If background is 0f, this does not change the background. Does not filter the
779     * given colors.
780     * @param x the x position to place the char at
781     * @param y the y position to place the char at
782     * @param cell an ICellVisible, which is often implemented outside of SquidLib; this uses its char and color.
783     * @param background the color to use for the cell; if null or fully transparent, nothing will change in the background
784     */
785    public void put(int x, int y, ICellVisible cell, float background)
786    {
787        put(x, y, cell.getSymbol(), cell.getPackedColor(), background);
788    }
789    /**
790     * Puts the char c at the position x,y with the given foreground and background colors as encoded floats, such as
791     * those produced by {@link Color#toFloatBits()}. If foreground is 0f, then this does not
792     * change the foreground contents. If background is 0f, this does not change the background. Does not filter the
793     * given colors.
794     * @param x the x position to place the char at
795     * @param y the y position to place the char at
796     * @param c the char to place
797     * @param foreground the color to use for c; if 0f, nothing will change in the foreground
798     * @param background the color to use for the cell; if null or fully transparent, nothing will change in the background
799     */
800    public void put(int x, int y, char c, float foreground, float background)
801    {
802        if(x < 0 || x >= gridWidth || y < 0 || y >= gridHeight)
803            return;
804        if(background != 0f)
805            backgrounds[x][y] = background;
806        if(foreground != 0f)
807            layers.get(0).place(x, y, c, foreground);
808    }
809
810
811    /**
812     * Puts the char c at the position x,y with the given foreground color as an encoded float (the kind produced by
813     * {@link Color#toFloatBits()}). If foreground is 0f, then this does nothing. Does not filter the given color.
814     * @param x the x position to place the char at
815     * @param y the y position to place the char at
816     * @param c the char to place
817     * @param foreground the color to use for c; if 0f, this call does nothing
818     */
819    public void put(int x, int y, char c, float foreground)
820    {
821        if(x < 0 || x >= gridWidth || y < 0 || y >= gridHeight || foreground == 0f)
822            return;
823        layers.get(0).place(x, y, c, foreground);
824    }
825    /**
826     * Puts the char c at the position x,y in the requested layer with the given foreground and background colors. If
827     * foreground is null or is fully transparent (all channels 0), then this does not change
828     * the foreground contents. If background is null or is fully transparent, this does not change the background. Uses
829     * the color center to potentially filter the given colors; this can be changed with
830     * {@link #setColorCenter(IColorCenter)}. The layer can be greater than the number of layers currently present,
831     * which will add a layer to be rendered over the existing layers, but the number that refers to that layer will not
832     * change. It is recommended that to add a layer, you only add at the value equal to {@link #getLayerCount()}, which
833     * will maintain the order and layer numbers in a sane way.
834     * @param x the x position to place the char at
835     * @param y the y position to place the char at
836     * @param c the char to place
837     * @param foreground the color to use for c; if null or fully transparent, nothing will change in the foreground
838     * @param background the color to use for the cell; if null or fully transparent, nothing will change in the background
839     * @param layer the layer to place the colorful char into; should usually be between 0 and {@link #getLayerCount()} inclusive
840     */
841    public void put(int x, int y, char c, Color foreground, Color background, int layer)
842    {
843        put(x, y, c, foreground == null ? 0f : scc.filter(foreground).toFloatBits(),
844                background == null ? 0f : scc.filter(background).toFloatBits(), layer);
845
846    }
847    /**
848     * Puts the char c at the position x,y in the requested layer with the given foreground and background colors as
849     * encoded floats, such as those produced by {@link Color#toFloatBits()}. If foreground is 0f, then this does not
850     * change the foreground contents. If background is 0f, this does not change the
851     * background. Does not filter the given colors. The layer can be greater than the number of layers currently
852     * present, which will add a layer to be rendered over the existing layers, but the number that refers to that layer
853     * will not change. It is recommended that to add a layer, you only add at the value equal to
854     * {@link #getLayerCount()}, which will maintain the order and layer numbers in a sane way.
855     * @param x the x position to place the char at
856     * @param y the y position to place the char at
857     * @param c the char to place
858     * @param foreground the color to use for c; if 0f, nothing will change in the foreground
859     * @param background the color to use for the cell; if null or fully transparent, nothing will change in the background
860     * @param layer the layer to place the colorful char into; should usually be between 0 and {@link #getLayerCount()} inclusive
861     */
862    public void put(int x, int y, char c, float foreground, float background, int layer)
863    {
864        if(x < 0 || x >= gridWidth || y < 0 || y >= gridHeight || layer < 0)
865            return;
866        if(background != 0f)
867            backgrounds[x][y] = background;
868        layer = mapping.get(layer, layer);
869        if(foreground != 0f)
870        {
871            if(layer >= layers.size())
872            {
873                mapping.put(layer, layers.size());
874                SparseTextMap stm = new SparseTextMap(gridWidth * gridHeight >> 4);
875                stm.place(x, y, c, foreground);
876                layers.add(stm);
877            }
878            else
879            {
880                layers.get(layer).place(x, y, c, foreground);
881            }
882        }
883    }
884    /**
885     * Puts text at the position x,y with the given foreground and background colors. If foreground is null or is
886     * fully transparent (all channels 0), then this does not change the foreground contents.
887     * If background is null or is fully transparent, this does not change the background. Uses the color center to
888     * potentially filter the given colors; this can be changed with {@link #setColorCenter(IColorCenter)}.
889     * @param x the x position to place the String at
890     * @param y the y position to place the String at
891     * @param text the String to place
892     * @param foreground the color to use for text; if null or fully transparent, nothing will change in the foreground
893     * @param background the color to use for the cells; if null or fully transparent, nothing will change in the background
894     */
895    public void put(int x, int y, String text, Color foreground, Color background) {
896        put(x, y, text, foreground == null ? 0f : scc.filter(foreground).toFloatBits(),
897                background == null ? 0f : scc.filter(background).toFloatBits());
898    }
899    /**
900     * Puts text at the position x,y with the given foreground and background colors as encoded floats, such as
901     * those produced by {@link Color#toFloatBits()}. If foreground is 0f, then this does not change the foreground
902     * contents. If background is 0f, this does not change the background. Does not filter the given colors.
903     * @param x the x position to place the String at
904     * @param y the y position to place the String at
905     * @param text the String to place
906     * @param foreground the color to use for text; if 0f, nothing will change in the foreground
907     * @param background the color to use for the cells; if null or fully transparent, nothing will change in the background
908     */
909    public void put(int x, int y, String text, float foreground, float background)
910    {
911        if(text != null) {
912            int len = Math.min(text.length(), gridWidth - x);
913            for (int i = 0; i < len; i++) {
914                put(x + i, y, text.charAt(i), foreground, background);
915            }
916        }
917    }
918    /**
919     * Puts text at the position x,y in the requested layer with the given foreground and background colors. If
920     * foreground is null or is fully transparent (all channels 0), then this does not change the foreground contents.
921     * If background is null or is fully transparent, this does not change the background. Uses the color center to
922     * potentially filter the given colors; this can be changed with {@link #setColorCenter(IColorCenter)}. The layer
923     * can be greater than the number of layers currently present, which will add a layer to be rendered over the
924     * existing layers, but the number that refers to that layer will not change. It is recommended that to add a layer,
925     * you only add at the value equal to {@link #getLayerCount()}, which will maintain the order and layer numbers in a
926     * sane way.
927     * @param x the x position to place the String at
928     * @param y the y position to place the String at
929     * @param text the String to place
930     * @param foreground the color to use for text; if null or fully transparent, nothing will change in the foreground
931     * @param background the color to use for the cells; if null or fully transparent, nothing will change in the background
932     * @param layer the layer to place the colorful char into; should usually be between 0 and {@link #getLayerCount()} inclusive
933     */
934    public void put(int x, int y, String text, Color foreground, Color background, int layer) {
935        put(x, y, text, foreground == null ? 0f : scc.filter(foreground).toFloatBits(),
936                background == null ? 0f : scc.filter(background).toFloatBits(), layer);
937    }
938    /**
939     * Puts text at the position x,y in the requested layer with the given foreground and background colors as encoded
940     * floats, such as those produced by {@link Color#toFloatBits()}. If foreground is 0f, then this does not change the
941     * foreground contents. If background is 0f, this does not change the background. Does not filter the given colors.
942     * The layer can be greater than the number of layers currently present, which will add a layer to be rendered over
943     * the existing layers, but the number that refers to that layer will not change. It is recommended that to add a
944     * layer, you only add at the value equal to {@link #getLayerCount()}, which will maintain the order and layer
945     * numbers in a sane way.
946     * @param x the x position to place the String at
947     * @param y the y position to place the String at
948     * @param text the String to place
949     * @param foreground the color to use for text; if 0f, nothing will change in the foreground
950     * @param background the color to use for the cells; if null or fully transparent, nothing will change in the background
951     * @param layer the layer to place the colorful char into; should usually be between 0 and {@link #getLayerCount()} inclusive
952     */
953    public void put(int x, int y, String text, float foreground, float background, int layer) {
954        if (x < 0 || x >= gridWidth || y < 0 || y >= gridHeight || layer < 0)
955            return;
956        int len = Math.min(text.length(), gridWidth - x);
957        if(background != 0f) {
958            for (int i = 0; i < len; i++) {
959                backgrounds[x + i][y] = background;
960            }
961        }
962        if (foreground != 0f)
963        {
964            layer = mapping.get(layer, layer);
965            if (layer >= layers.size()) {
966                mapping.put(layer, layers.size());
967                SparseTextMap stm = new SparseTextMap(gridWidth * gridHeight >> 4);
968                for (int i = 0; i < len; i++) {
969                    stm.place(x + i, y, text.charAt(i), foreground);
970                }
971                layers.add(stm);
972            } else {
973                SparseTextMap stm = layers.get(layer);
974                for (int i = 0; i < len; i++) {
975                    stm.place(x + i, y, text.charAt(i), foreground);
976                }
977            }
978        }
979    }
980
981    /**
982     * Changes the background at position x,y to the given Color. If the color is null, then this will make the
983     * background fully transparent at the specified position.
984     * @param x where to change the background color, x-coordinate
985     * @param y where to change the background color, y-coordinate
986     * @param color the Color to change to; if null will be considered fully transparent
987     */
988    public void put(int x, int y, Color color)
989    {
990        put(x, y, color == null ? 0f : scc.filter(color).toFloatBits());
991    }
992    /**
993     * Changes the background at position x,y to the given color as an encoded float. The color can be transparent,
994     * which will show through to whatever is behind this SparseLayers, or the color the screen was last cleared with.
995     * Unlike other methods in this class, a float equal to 0f will be used instead of being used to skip over a cell,
996     * and will change the background at the given position to fully transparent.
997     * @param x where to change the background color, x-coordinate
998     * @param y where to change the background color, y-coordinate
999     * @param color the color, as an encoded float, to change to; may be transparent, and considers 0f a valid color
1000     */
1001    public void put(int x, int y, float color)
1002    {
1003        if(x < 0 || x >= gridWidth || y < 0 || y >= gridHeight)
1004            return;
1005        backgrounds[x][y] = color;
1006    }
1007    /**
1008     * A convenience method that handles blending the background color with a specified light color, by a specific
1009     * amount, without putting a char on the screen; as a whole this affects one x,y position.
1010     * @param x the x position, in cells
1011     * @param y the y position, in cells
1012     * @param background the "base" color to use for the background, which will be combined with lightColor, as a libGDX Color
1013     * @param lightColor the color to mix with the background, as a libGDX Color
1014     * @param lightAmount a float that determines how much lightColor should affect background by; not strictly limited
1015     *                    to between 0 and 1, and negative values can be given to favor background more
1016     */
1017    public void putWithLight(int x, int y, Color background, Color lightColor, float lightAmount) {
1018        putWithLight(x, y, '\0', 0f, background == null ? 0f :  background.toFloatBits(),
1019                lightColor == null ? 0f : lightColor.toFloatBits(), lightAmount);
1020    }
1021    /**
1022     * A convenience method that handles blending the background color with a specified light color, by a specific
1023     * amount, without putting a char on the screen; as a whole this affects one x,y position.
1024     * @param x the x position, in cells
1025     * @param y the y position, in cells
1026     * @param background the "base" color to use for the background, which will be combined with lightColor, as a libGDX Color
1027     * @param lightColor the color to mix with the background, as a libGDX Color
1028     * @param lightAmount a double that determines how much lightColor should affect background by; not strictly limited
1029     *                    to between 0 and 1, and negative values can be given to favor background more
1030     */
1031    public void putWithLight(int x, int y, Color background, Color lightColor, double lightAmount) {
1032        putWithLight(x, y, '\0', 0f, background == null ? 0f :  background.toFloatBits(),
1033                lightColor == null ? 0f : lightColor.toFloatBits(), lightAmount);
1034    }
1035
1036    /**
1037     * A convenience method that handles blending the background color with a specified light color, by a specific
1038     * amount, while also putting a char on the screen; as a whole this affects one x,y position.
1039     * @param x the x position, in cells
1040     * @param y the y position, in cells
1041     * @param c the char to put in the foreground
1042     * @param foreground the color to use for the foreground, as a libGDX Color; if null, this won't place a foreground char
1043     * @param background the "base" color to use for the background, which will be combined with lightColor, as a libGDX Color
1044     * @param lightColor the color to mix with the background, as a libGDX Color
1045     * @param lightAmount a float that determines how much lightColor should affect background by; not strictly limited
1046     *                    to between 0 and 1, and negative values can be given to favor background more
1047     */
1048    public void putWithLight(int x, int y, char c, Color foreground, Color background, Color lightColor, float lightAmount) {
1049        putWithLight(x, y, c, foreground == null ? 0f : foreground.toFloatBits(), background == null ? 0f :  background.toFloatBits(),
1050                lightColor == null ? 0f : lightColor.toFloatBits(), lightAmount);
1051    }
1052
1053    /**
1054     * A convenience method that handles blending the background color with a specified light color, by a specific
1055     * amount, while also putting a char on the screen; as a whole this affects one x,y position.
1056     * @param x the x position, in cells
1057     * @param y the y position, in cells
1058     * @param c the char to put in the foreground
1059     * @param foreground the color to use for the foreground, as a libGDX Color; if null, this won't place a foreground char
1060     * @param background the "base" color to use for the background, which will be combined with lightColor, as a libGDX Color
1061     * @param lightColor the color to mix with the background, as a libGDX Color
1062     * @param lightAmount a double that determines how much lightColor should affect background by; not strictly limited
1063     *                    to between 0 and 1, and negative values can be given to favor background more
1064     */
1065    public void putWithLight(int x, int y, char c, Color foreground, Color background, Color lightColor, double lightAmount) {
1066        putWithLight(x, y, c, foreground == null ? 0f : foreground.toFloatBits(), background == null ? 0f :  background.toFloatBits(),
1067                lightColor == null ? 0f : lightColor.toFloatBits(), lightAmount);
1068    }
1069
1070    /**
1071     * A convenience method that handles blending the background color with a specified light color, by a specific
1072     * amount, without putting a char on the screen; as a whole this affects one x,y position. This will use the same
1073     * brightness for all cells given identical lightAmount values when this is called; this differentiates it from
1074     * {@link #putWithLight(int, int, float, float, float, Noise.Noise3D)}, which would light "splotches" of map with
1075     * brighter or darker color. Instead, if lightAmount is obtained via SquidLib's {@code FOV} class, then all cells
1076     * at a short distance from an FOV center will be lit brightly and cells far away will flicker in and out of view.
1077     * @param x the x position, in cells
1078     * @param y the y position, in cells
1079     * @param background the "base" color to use for the background, which will be combined with lightColor, as a packed float color
1080     * @param lightColor the color to mix with the background, as a packed float color
1081     * @param lightAmount a float that determines how much lightColor should affect background by; not strictly limited
1082     *                    to between 0 and 1, and negative values can be given to favor background more
1083     */
1084    public void putWithConsistentLight(int x, int y, float background, float lightColor, float lightAmount) {
1085        putWithConsistentLight(x, y, background, lightColor, lightAmount, 0.0015f);
1086    }
1087    /**
1088     * A convenience method that handles blending the background color with a specified light color, by a specific
1089     * amount, without putting a char on the screen; as a whole this affects one x,y position. This will use the same
1090     * brightness for all cells given identical lightAmount values when this is called; this differentiates it from
1091     * {@link #putWithLight(int, int, float, float, float, Noise.Noise3D)}, which would light "splotches" of map with
1092     * brighter or darker color. Instead, if lightAmount is obtained via SquidLib's {@code FOV} class, then all cells
1093     * at a short distance from an FOV center will be lit brightly and cells far away will flicker in and out of view.
1094     * @param x the x position, in cells
1095     * @param y the y position, in cells
1096     * @param background the "base" color to use for the background, which will be combined with lightColor, as a packed float color
1097     * @param lightColor the color to mix with the background, as a packed float color
1098     * @param lightAmount a float that determines how much lightColor should affect background by; not strictly limited
1099     *                    to between 0 and 1, and negative values can be given to favor background more
1100     * @param flickerSpeed a small float multiplier applied to the time in milliseconds; often between 0.0005f and 0.005f
1101     */
1102    public void putWithConsistentLight(int x, int y, float background, float lightColor, float lightAmount, float flickerSpeed) {
1103        final float time = (System.currentTimeMillis() & 0xffffffL) * flickerSpeed;
1104        final long time0 = Noise.longFloor(time);
1105        final float noise = Noise.querp(NumberTools.randomFloatCurved(time0), NumberTools.randomFloatCurved(time0 + 1L), time - time0);
1106        lightAmount = Math.max(lightAmount * 0.15f, Math.min(lightAmount - NumberTools.swayTight(noise * 3.141592f) * 0.15f - 0.1f + 0.25f * noise, lightAmount));
1107        putWithLight(x, y, '\0', 0f, background, lightColor, lightAmount);
1108    }
1109
1110    /**
1111     * Gets a modifier that should be given to {@link #calculateConsistentLightAmount(float, float)}; this only needs to
1112     * be called at most once per frame. It uses a flickerSpeed of 0.0015f, if you want to compare it to
1113     * {@link #calculateConsistentLightModifier(float)}.
1114     * @return a modifier to pass to {@link #calculateConsistentLightAmount(float, float)}
1115     */
1116    public float calculateConsistentLightModifier()
1117    {
1118        return calculateConsistentLightModifier(0.0015f);
1119    }
1120    /**
1121     * Gets a modifier that should be given to {@link #calculateConsistentLightAmount(float, float)}; this only needs to
1122     * be called at most once per frame. It uses the given flickerSpeed; a common example value is 0.0015f.
1123     * @return a modifier to pass to {@link #calculateConsistentLightAmount(float, float)}
1124     */
1125    public float calculateConsistentLightModifier(float flickerSpeed)
1126    {
1127        final float time = (System.currentTimeMillis() & 0xffffffL) * flickerSpeed;
1128        final long time0 = Noise.longFloor(time);
1129        return Noise.querp(NumberTools.randomFloatCurved(time0), NumberTools.randomFloatCurved(time0 + 1L), time - time0);
1130    }
1131
1132    /**
1133     * Allows you to reproduce the effects of {@link #putWithConsistentLight(int, int, char, float, float, float, double, float)}
1134     * without recalculating the modifier many times per frame. You should typically calculate the modifier once per
1135     * frame using {@link #calculateConsistentLightModifier()}. This method should usually be called once per cell that
1136     * needs consistent lighting that flickers the same in all directions.
1137     * @param lightAmount typically from FOV or some other way of generating a float with lower values further from a position (such as a light)
1138     * @param modifier calculated previously by {@link #calculateConsistentLightModifier()}, which should be done per-frame
1139     * @return the adjusted light amount to mimic the appearance of {@link #putWithConsistentLight(int, int, char, float, float, float, double, float)}
1140     */
1141    public float calculateConsistentLightAmount(float lightAmount, float modifier)
1142    {
1143        return lightAmount <= 0f ? -1024f : Math.max(
1144                lightAmount * 0.15f,
1145                Math.min(lightAmount - NumberTools.swayTight(modifier * 3.141592f) * 0.15f - 0.1f + 0.25f * modifier, lightAmount));
1146    }
1147    
1148    /**
1149     * A convenience method that handles blending the background color with a specified light color, by a specific
1150     * amount, without putting a char on the screen; as a whole this affects one x,y position. This will use the same
1151     * brightness for all cells given identical lightAmount values when this is called; this differentiates it from
1152     * {@link #putWithLight(int, int, float, float, float, Noise.Noise3D)}, which would light "splotches" of map with
1153     * brighter or darker color. Instead, if lightAmount is obtained via SquidLib's {@code FOV} class, then all cells
1154     * at a short distance from an FOV center will be lit brightly and cells far away will flicker in and out of view.
1155     * @param x the x position, in cells
1156     * @param y the y position, in cells
1157     * @param background the "base" color to use for the background, which will be combined with lightColor, as a libGDX Color
1158     * @param lightColor the color to mix with the background, as a libGDX Color
1159     * @param lightAmount a float that determines how much lightColor should affect background by; not strictly limited
1160     *                    to between 0 and 1, and negative values can be given to favor background more
1161     */
1162    public void putWithConsistentLight(int x, int y, Color background, Color lightColor, float lightAmount) {
1163        putWithConsistentLight(x, y, background, lightColor, lightAmount, 0.0015f);
1164    }
1165    /**
1166     * A convenience method that handles blending the background color with a specified light color, by a specific
1167     * amount, without putting a char on the screen; as a whole this affects one x,y position. This will use the same
1168     * brightness for all cells given identical lightAmount values when this is called; this differentiates it from
1169     * {@link #putWithLight(int, int, float, float, float, Noise.Noise3D)}, which would light "splotches" of map with
1170     * brighter or darker color. Instead, if lightAmount is obtained via SquidLib's {@code FOV} class, then all cells
1171     * at a short distance from an FOV center will be lit brightly and cells far away will flicker in and out of view.
1172     * @param x the x position, in cells
1173     * @param y the y position, in cells
1174     * @param background the "base" color to use for the background, which will be combined with lightColor, as a libGDX Color
1175     * @param lightColor the color to mix with the background, as a libGDX Color
1176     * @param lightAmount a float that determines how much lightColor should affect background by; not strictly limited
1177     *                    to between 0 and 1, and negative values can be given to favor background more
1178     * @param flickerSpeed a small float multiplier applied to the time in milliseconds; often between 0.0005f and 0.005f
1179     */
1180    public void putWithConsistentLight(int x, int y, Color background, Color lightColor, float lightAmount, float flickerSpeed) {
1181        final float time = (System.currentTimeMillis() & 0xffffffL) * flickerSpeed; // if you want to adjust the speed of flicker, change the multiplier
1182        final long time0 = Noise.longFloor(time);
1183        final float noise = Noise.querp(NumberTools.randomFloatCurved(time0), NumberTools.randomFloatCurved(time0 + 1L), time - time0);
1184        lightAmount = Math.max(lightAmount * 0.15f, Math.min(lightAmount - NumberTools.swayTight(noise * 3.141592f) * 0.15f - 0.1f + 0.25f * noise, lightAmount)); // 0.1f * noise for light theme, 0.2f * noise for dark theme
1185        putWithLight(x, y, '\0', 0f, background == null ? 0f :  background.toFloatBits(),
1186                lightColor == null ? 0f : lightColor.toFloatBits(), lightAmount);
1187    }

1189     * A convenience method that handles blending the background color with a specified light color, by a specific
1190     * amount, without putting a char on the screen; as a whole this affects one x,y position. This will use the same
1191     * brightness for all cells given identical lightAmount values when this is called; this differentiates it from

1194     * at a short distance from an FOV center will be lit brightly and cells far away will flicker in and out of view.

1196     * @param y the y position, in cells

1198     * @param background the "base" color to use for the background, which will be combined with lightColor, as a packed float color
1199     * @param lightColor the color to mix with the background, as a packed float color
1200     * @param lightAmount a float that determines how much lightColor should affect background by; not strictly limited
1201     *                    to between 0 and 1, and negative values can be given to favor background more
1202     */

1236     * @param lightColor the color to mix with the background, as a packed float color

1240     */
1241    public void putWithConsistentLight(int x, int y, char c, float foreground, float background, float lightColor, double lightAmount, float flickerSpeed) {
1242        final float time = (System.currentTimeMillis() & 0xffffffL) * flickerSpeed; // if you want to adjust the speed of flicker, change the multiplier
1243        final long time0 = Noise.longFloor(time);
1244        final float noise = Noise.querp(NumberTools.randomFloatCurved(time0), NumberTools.randomFloatCurved(time0 + 1L), time - time0);
1245        lightAmount = Math.max(lightAmount * 0.15f, Math.min(lightAmount - NumberTools.swayTight(noise * 3.141592f) * 0.15f - 0.1f + 0.25f * noise, lightAmount)); // 0.1f * noise for light theme, 0.2f * noise for dark theme
1246        putWithLight(x, y, c, foreground, background, lightColor, lightAmount);
1247    }
1248    /**
1249     * A convenience method that handles blending the foreground color with a specified light color, by a specific
1250     * amount, without putting a char on the screen; as a whole this affects one x,y position and placed the background
1251     * as-is. This will use the same brightness for all cells given identical lightAmount values when this is called;
1252     * this differentiates it from {@link #putWithLight(int, int, float, float, float, Noise.Noise3D)}, which would
1253     * light "splotches" of map with brighter or darker color. Instead, if lightAmount is obtained via SquidLib's
1254     * {@code FOV} class, then all cells at a short distance from an FOV center will be lit brightly and cells far away
1255     * will flicker in and out of view.

1257     * @param y the y position, in cells
1258     * @param c the char to draw; may be {@code '\0'} to draw a solid block
1259     * @param foreground the "base" color to use for the foreground, which will be combined with lightColor, as a packed float color
1260     * @param background the "base" color to use for the background, which will used without modification, as a packed float color
1261     * @param lightColor the color to mix with the foreground, as a packed float color
1262     * @param lightAmount a float that determines how much lightColor should affect foreground by; not strictly limited
1263     *                    to between 0 and 1, and negative values can be given to favor foreground more
1264     */
1265    public void putWithReverseConsistentLight(int x, int y, char c, float foreground, float background, float lightColor, float lightAmount) {

1396     * @param y the y position, in cells
1397     * @param c the char to draw; may be {@code '\0'} to draw a solid block
1398     * @param foreground the "base" color to use for the foreground, which will be combined with lightColor, as a libGDX Color
1399     * @param background the "base" color to use for the background, which will used without modification
1400     * @param lightColor the color to mix with the foreground, as a libGDX Color
1401     * @param lightAmount a double that determines how much lightColor should affect foreground by; not strictly limited
1402     *                    to between 0 and 1, and negative values can be given to favor foreground more
1403     * @param flickerSpeed a small float multiplier applied to the time in milliseconds; often between 0.0005f and 0.005f
1404     */
1405    public void putWithReverseConsistentLight(int x, int y, char c, Color foreground, Color background, Color lightColor, double lightAmount, float flickerSpeed) {
1406        final float time = (System.currentTimeMillis() & 0xffffffL) * flickerSpeed; // if you want to adjust the speed of flicker, change the multiplier
1407        final long time0 = Noise.longFloor(time);
1408        final float noise = Noise.querp(NumberTools.randomFloatCurved(time0), NumberTools.randomFloatCurved(time0 + 1L), time - time0);
1409        lightAmount = Math.max(lightAmount * 0.15f, Math.min(lightAmount - NumberTools.swayTight(noise * 3.141592f) * 0.15f - 0.1f + 0.25f * noise, lightAmount)); // 0.1f * noise for light theme, 0.2f * noise for dark theme
1410        putWithReverseLight(x, y, c, foreground == null ? 0f : foreground.toFloatBits(), background == null ? 0f :  background.toFloatBits(),
1411                lightColor == null ? 0f : lightColor.toFloatBits(), lightAmount);
1412    }
1413
1414    /**
1415     * A convenience method that handles blending the background color with a specified light color, by a specific
1416     * amount, without putting a char on the screen; as a whole this affects one x,y position.
1417     * @param x the x position, in cells
1418     * @param y the y position, in cells
1419     * @param background the "base" color to use for the background, which will be combined with lightColor, as a packed float
1420     * @param lightColor the color to mix with the background, as a packed float
1421     * @param lightAmount a float that determines how much lightColor should affect background by; not strictly limited
1422     *                    to between 0 and 1, and negative values can be given to favor background more
1423     */
1424    public void putWithLight(int x, int y, float background, float lightColor, float lightAmount) {
1425        put(x, y, '\0', 0f,
1426                SColor.lerpFloatColors(background, lightColor,
1427                        MathUtils.clamp(0xAAp-9f + (0xC8p-9f * lightAmount), 0f, 1f)));
1428    }
1429    /**
1430     * A convenience method that handles blending the background color with a specified light color, by a specific
1431     * amount, without putting a char on the screen; as a whole this affects one x,y position.
1432     * @param x the x position, in cells
1433     * @param y the y position, in cells
1434     * @param background the "base" color to use for the background, which will be combined with lightColor, as a packed float
1435     * @param lightColor the color to mix with the background, as a packed float
1436     * @param lightAmount a double that determines how much lightColor should affect background by; not strictly limited
1437     *                    to between 0 and 1, and negative values can be given to favor background more
1438     */
1439    public void putWithLight(int x, int y, float background, float lightColor, double lightAmount) {
1440        put(x, y, '\0', 0f,
1441                SColor.lerpFloatColors(background, lightColor,
1442                        MathUtils.clamp(0xAAp-9f + (0xC8p-9f * (float) lightAmount), 0f, 1f)));
1443    }

1445    /**
1446     * A convenience method that handles blending the background color with a specified light color, by a specific
1447     * amount, while also putting a char on the screen; as a whole this affects one x,y position.
1448     * @param x the x position, in cells
1449     * @param y the y position, in cells
1450     * @param c the char to put in the foreground
1451     * @param foreground the color to use for the foreground, as a packed float; if 0f, this won't place a foreground char
1452     * @param background the "base" color to use for the background, which will be combined with lightColor, as a packed float
1453     * @param lightColor the color to mix with the background, as a packed float
1454     * @param lightAmount a float that determines how much lightColor should affect background by; not strictly limited
1455     *                    to between 0 and 1, and negative values can be given to favor background more
1456     */
1457    public void putWithLight(int x, int y, char c, float foreground, float background, float lightColor, float lightAmount) {
1458        put(x, y, c, foreground,
1459                SColor.lerpFloatColors(background, lightColor,
1460                        MathUtils.clamp(0xAAp-9f + (0xC8p-9f * lightAmount), 0f, 1f)));
1461    }

1464     * A convenience method that handles blending the background color with a specified light color, by a specific
1465     * amount, while also putting a char on the screen; as a whole this affects one x,y position.

1467     * @param y the y position, in cells
1468     * @param c the char to put in the foreground
1469     * @param foreground the color to use for the foreground, as a packed float; if 0f, this won't place a foreground char
1470     * @param background the "base" color to use for the background, which will be combined with lightColor, as a packed float
1471     * @param lightColor the color to mix with the background, as a packed float
1472     * @param lightAmount a double that determines how much lightColor should affect background by; not strictly limited
1473     *                    to between 0 and 1, and negative values can be given to favor background more
1474     */
1475    public void putWithLight(int x, int y, char c, float foreground, float background, float lightColor, double lightAmount) {

1477                SColor.lerpFloatColors(background, lightColor,
1478                        MathUtils.clamp(0xAAp-9f + (0xC8p-9f * (float) lightAmount), 0f, 1f)));

1481    /**
1482     * A convenience method that handles blending the background color with a specified light color, by a specific
1483     * amount, while also putting a char on the screen; as a whole this affects one x,y position.
1484     * @param x the x position, in cells
1485     * @param y the y position, in cells
1486     * @param c the char to put in the foreground
1487     * @param foreground the color to use for the foreground, as a packed float; if 0f, this won't place a foreground char
1488     * @param background the "base" color to use for the background, which will be combined with lightColor, as a packed float
1489     * @param lightColor the color to mix with the background, as a packed float
1490     * @param lightAmount a float that determines how much lightColor should affect background by; not strictly limited
1491     *                    to between 0 and 1, and negative values can be given to favor background more
1492     */
1493    public void putWithReverseLight(int x, int y, char c, float foreground, float background, float lightColor, float lightAmount) {
1494        put(x, y, c, SColor.lerpFloatColors(foreground, lightColor,
1495                MathUtils.clamp(0x88p-9f + (0xC8p-9f * lightAmount), 0f, 1f)), background);
1496    }

1498    /**
1499     * A convenience method that handles blending the background color with a specified light color, by a specific
1500     * amount, while also putting a char on the screen; as a whole this affects one x,y position.

1505     * @param background the "base" color to use for the background, which will be combined with lightColor, as a packed float
1506     * @param lightColor the color to mix with the background, as a packed float
1507     * @param lightAmount a double that determines how much lightColor should affect background by; not strictly limited
1508     *                    to between 0 and 1, and negative values can be given to favor background more
1509     */
1510    public void putWithReverseLight(int x, int y, char c, float foreground, float background, float lightColor, double lightAmount) {

1512                MathUtils.clamp(0x88p-9f + (0xC8p-9f * (float) lightAmount), 0f, 1f)), background);

1514    /**
1515     * A convenience method that handles blending the background color with a specified light color, by a specific
1516     * amount that will be adjusted by the given {@link Noise.Noise3D} object, without putting a char on the screen;
1517     * as a whole this affects one x,y position and will change what it puts as the time (in milliseconds) changes. If
1518     * {@code flicker} is null, this will default to using {@link WhirlingNoise}. You can make the lighting dimmer by
1519     * using a darker color for {@code lightColor} or by giving a lower value for {@code lightAmount}.
1520     * @param x the x position, in cells
1521     * @param y the y position, in cells
1522     * @param background the "base" color to use for the background, which will be combined with lightColor, as a libGDX Color
1523     * @param lightColor the color to mix with the background, as a libGDX Color
1524     * @param lightAmount a float that determines how much lightColor should affect background by; not strictly limited
1525     *                    to between 0 and 1, and negative values can be given to favor background more
1526     *@param flicker a Noise.Noise3D instance, such as {@link WhirlingNoise#instance}; may be null to use WhirlingNoise
1527     */
1528    public void putWithLight(int x, int y, Color background, Color lightColor, float lightAmount, Noise.Noise3D flicker) {
1529        putWithLight(x, y, '\0', 0f, background == null ? 0f :  background.toFloatBits(),
1530                lightColor == null ? 0f : lightColor.toFloatBits(), lightAmount, flicker);
1531    }
1532    /**
1533     * A convenience method that handles blending the background color with a specified light color, by a specific
1534     * amount that will be adjusted by the given {@link Noise.Noise3D} object, while also putting a char on the screen;
