1535     * as a whole this affects one x,y position and will change what it puts as the time (in milliseconds) changes. If
1536     * {@code flicker} is null, this will default to using {@link WhirlingNoise}. You can make the lighting dimmer by
1537     * using a darker color for {@code lightColor} or by giving a lower value for {@code lightAmount}.
1538     * @param x the x position, in cells
1539     * @param y the y position, in cells
1540     * @param c the char to put in the foreground
1541     * @param foreground the color to use for the foreground, as a libGDX Color; if null, this won't place a foreground char
1542     * @param background the "base" color to use for the background, which will be combined with lightColor, as a libGDX Color
1543     * @param lightColor the color to mix with the background, as a libGDX Color
1544     * @param lightAmount a float that determines how much lightColor should affect background by; not strictly limited
1545     *                    to between 0 and 1, and negative values can be given to favor background more
1546     *@param flicker a Noise.Noise3D instance, such as {@link WhirlingNoise#instance}; may be null to use WhirlingNoise
1547     */
1548    public void putWithLight(int x, int y, char c, Color foreground, Color background, Color lightColor, float lightAmount, Noise.Noise3D flicker) {
1549        putWithLight(x, y, c, foreground == null ? 0f : foreground.toFloatBits(), background == null ? 0f :  background.toFloatBits(),
1550                lightColor == null ? 0f : lightColor.toFloatBits(), lightAmount, flicker);
1551    }
1552    /**
1553     * A convenience method that handles blending the background color with a specified light color, by a specific
1554     * amount that will be adjusted by the given {@link Noise.Noise3D} object, without putting a char on the screen;
1555     * as a whole this affects one x,y position and will change what it puts as the time (in milliseconds) changes. If
1556     * {@code flicker} is null, this will default to using {@link WhirlingNoise}. You can make the lighting dimmer by
1557     * using a darker color for {@code lightColor} or by giving a lower value for {@code lightAmount}.
1558     * @param x the x position, in cells
1559     * @param y the y position, in cells
1560     * @param background the "base" color to use for the background, which will be combined with lightColor, as a packed float color
1561     * @param lightColor the color to mix with the background, as a packed float color
1562     * @param lightAmount a float that determines how much lightColor should affect background by; not strictly limited
1563     *                    to between 0 and 1, and negative values can be given to favor background more
1564     *@param flicker a Noise.Noise3D instance, such as {@link WhirlingNoise#instance}; may be null to use WhirlingNoise
1565     */
1566    public void putWithLight(int x, int y, float background, float lightColor, float lightAmount, Noise.Noise3D flicker) {
1567        putWithLight(x, y, '\0', 0f, background, lightColor, lightAmount, flicker);
1568    }
1569    /**
1570     * A convenience method that handles blending the background color with a specified light color, by a specific
1571     * amount that will be adjusted by the given {@link Noise.Noise3D} object, while also putting a char on the screen;
1572     * as a whole this affects one x,y position and will change what it puts as the time (in milliseconds) changes. If
1573     * {@code flicker} is null, this will default to using {@link WhirlingNoise}. You can make the lighting dimmer by
1574     * using a darker color for {@code lightColor} or by giving a lower value for {@code lightAmount}.
1575     * @param x the x position, in cells
1576     * @param y the y position, in cells
1577     * @param c the char to put in the foreground
1578     * @param foreground the color to use for the foreground, as a packed float; if 0f, this won't place a foreground char
1579     * @param background the "base" color to use for the background, which will be combined with lightColor, as a packed float color
1580     * @param lightColor the color to mix with the background, as a packed float color
1581     * @param lightAmount a float that determines how much lightColor should affect background by; not strictly limited
1582     *                    to between 0 and 1, and negative values can be given to favor background more
1583     *@param flicker a Noise.Noise3D instance, such as {@link WhirlingNoise#instance}; may be null to use WhirlingNoise
1584     */
1585    public void putWithLight(int x, int y, char c, float foreground, float background, float lightColor, float lightAmount, Noise.Noise3D flicker) {
1586        if(flicker == null)
1587            put(x, y, c, foreground,
1588                    SColor.lerpFloatColors(background, lightColor,(0xAAp-9f + (0xC8p-9f * lightAmount *
1589                            (1f + 0.35f * (float) WhirlingNoise.noise(x * 0.3, y * 0.3, (System.currentTimeMillis() & 0xffffffL) * 0.00125))))));
1590        else
1591            put(x, y, c, foreground,
1592                SColor.lerpFloatColors(background, lightColor,(0xAAp-9f + (0xC8p-9f * lightAmount *
1593                        (1f + 0.35f * (float) flicker.getNoise(x * 0.3, y * 0.3, (System.currentTimeMillis() & 0xffffffL) * 0.00125))))));
1594    }
1595    public void putBorders(float color, String caption)
1596    {
1597        put(0, 0,'┌', color);
1598        put(gridWidth - 1, 0,'┐', color);
1599        put(0, gridHeight - 1,'└', color);
1600        put(gridWidth - 1, gridHeight - 1,'┘', color);
1601        for (int i = 1; i < gridWidth - 1; i++) {
1602            put(i, 0, '─', color);
1603            put(i, gridHeight - 1, '─', color);
1604        }
1605        for (int y = 1; y < gridHeight - 1; y++) {
1606            put(0, y, '│', color);
1607            put(gridWidth - 1, y, '│', color);
1608        }
1609        for (int y = 1; y < gridHeight - 1; y++) {
1610            for (int x = 1; x < gridWidth - 1; x++) {
1611                clear(x, y, 0);
1612            }
1613        }
1614
1615        if (caption != null) {
1616            put(1, 0, caption, color, 0f);
1617        }
1618    }
1619
1620    /**
1621     *
1622     * @param color the color to draw the borders with; does not affect caption's color(s)
1623     * @param caption an IColoredString
1624     */
1625    public void putBordersCaptioned(float color, IColoredString<Color> caption)
1626    {
1627        put(0, 0,'┌', color);
1628        put(gridWidth - 1, 0,'┐', color);
1629        put(0, gridHeight - 1,'└', color);
1630        put(gridWidth - 1, gridHeight - 1,'┘', color);
1631        for (int i = 1; i < gridWidth - 1; i++) {
1632            put(i, 0, '─', color);
1633            put(i, gridHeight - 1, '─', color);
1634        }
1635        for (int y = 1; y < gridHeight - 1; y++) {
1636            put(0, y, '│', color);
1637            put(gridWidth - 1, y, '│', color);
1638        }
1639        for (int y = 1; y < gridHeight - 1; y++) {
1640            for (int x = 1; x < gridWidth - 1; x++) {
1641                clear(x, y, 0);
1642            }
1643        }
1644
1645        if (caption != null) {
1646            put(1, 0, caption);
1647        }
1648    }
1649
1650    /**
1651     * Removes the foreground chars, where present, in all layers at the given x,y position.
1652     * The backgrounds will be unchanged.
1653     * @param x the x-coordinate of the position to remove all chars from
1654     * @param y the y-coordinate of the position to remove all chars from
1655     */
1656    @Override
1657    public void clear(int x, int y)
1658    {
1659        if(x < 0 || x >= gridWidth || y < 0 || y >= gridHeight)
1660            return;
1661        backgrounds[x][y] = 0f;
1662        int code = SparseTextMap.encodePosition(x, y);
1663        for (int i = 0; i < layers.size(); i++) {
1664            layers.get(i).remove(code);
1665        }
1666    }
1667
1668    /**
1669     * Removes the foreground char, if present, in the given layer at the given x,y position.
1670     * The backgrounds and other layers will be unchanged.
1671     * @param x the x-coordinate of the position to remove all chars from
1672     * @param y the y-coordinate of the position to remove all chars from
1673     * @param layer the layer to remove from
1674     */
1675    public void clear(int x, int y, int layer)
1676    {
1677        layer = mapping.get(layer, -1);
1678        if(layer >= 0)
1679        {
1680            layers.get(layer).remove(SparseTextMap.encodePosition(x, y));
1681        }
1682    }
1683
1684    /**
1685     * Removes all background colors, setting them to transparent, and all foreground chars in all layers.
1686     */
1687    @Override
1688    public void clear()
1689    {
1690        ArrayTools.fill(backgrounds, 0f);
1691        for (int i = 0; i < layers.size(); i++) {
1692            layers.get(i).clear();
1693        }
1694    }
1695
1696    /**
1697     * Removes all foreground chars in the requested layer; does not affect the background or other layers.
1698     */
1699    public void clear(int layer)
1700    {
1701        int lay = mapping.get(layer, -1);
1702        if(lay >= 0)
1703            layers.get(lay).clear();
1704    }
1705    /**
1706     * Fills all of the background with the given color as libGDX Color object.
1707     * @param color the color to use for all of the background, as a libGDX Color or some subclass like SColor
1708     */
1709    public void fillBackground(Color color)
1710    {
1711        ArrayTools.fill(backgrounds, color == null ? 0f : scc.filter(color).toFloatBits());
1712    }
1713
1714    /**
1715     * Fills all of the background with the given color as a packed float.
1716     * @param color the color to use for all of the background, as a packed float
1717     */
1718    public void fillBackground(float color)
1719    {
1720        ArrayTools.fill(backgrounds, color);
1721    }
1722
1723    /**
1724     * Changes the background color in an area to all have the given color, as a libGDX Color (or SColor, etc.).
1725     * @param color a libGDX Color to fill the area with; may be null to make the background transparent
1726     * @param x left edge's x coordinate, in cells
1727     * @param y top edge's y coordinate, in cells
1728     * @param width the width of the area to change the color on
1729     * @param height the height of the area to change the color on
1730     */
1731    public void fillArea(Color color, int x, int y, int width, int height) {
1732        fillArea(color == null ? 0f : scc.filter(color).toFloatBits(), x, y, width, height);
1733    }
1734    /**
1735     * Changes the background color in an area to all have the given color, as a packed float.
1736     * @param color a color as a packed float to fill the area with; may be 0f to make the background transparent
1737     * @param x left edge's x coordinate, in cells
1738     * @param y top edge's y coordinate, in cells
1739     * @param width the width of the area to change the color on
1740     * @param height the height of the area to change the color on
1741     */
1742    public void fillArea(float color, int x, int y, int width, int height) {
1743        if (x < 0) {
1744            width += x;
1745            x = 0;
1746        }
1747        if (y < 0) {
1748            height += y;
1749            y = 0;
1750        }
1751        if (width <= 0 || height <= 0)
1752            return;
1753        for (int i = 0, xx = x; i < width && xx < gridWidth; i++, xx++) {
1754            for (int j = 0, yy = y; j < height && yy < gridHeight; j++, yy++) {
1755                backgrounds[xx][yy] = color;
1756            }
1757        }
1758    }
1759
1760    /**
1761     * Gets whether any animations or other scene2d Actions are running on this SparseLayers.
1762     * @return true if any animations or Actions are currently running, false otherwise
1763     */
1764    @Override
1765    public boolean hasActiveAnimations()
1766    {
1767        if(hasActions())
1768            return true;
1769        for (int i = 0; i < glyphs.size(); i++) {
1770            if(glyphs.get(i).hasActions()) return true;
1771        }
1772        return false;
1773    }
1774
1775    /**
1776     * Gets a direct reference to the 2D float array this uses for background colors.
1777     * @return a direct reference to the 2D float array this uses for background colors.
1778     */
1779    public float[][] getBackgrounds() {
1780        return backgrounds;
1781    }
1782
1783    /**
1784     * Changes the reference this uses for the float array for background colors; this will not accept null parameters,
1785     * nor will it accept any 2D array with dimensions that do not match the (unchanging) gridWidth and gridHeight of
1786     * this SparseLayers.
1787     * @param backgrounds a non-null 2D float array of colors; must have width == gridWidth and height == gridHeight
1788     */
1789    public void setBackgrounds(float[][] backgrounds) {
1790        if(backgrounds == null || backgrounds[0] == null)
1791            throw new IllegalArgumentException("SparseLayers.backgrounds must not be set to null");
1792        if(backgrounds.length != gridWidth || backgrounds[0].length != gridHeight)
1793            throw new IllegalArgumentException("Must be given a 2D array with equal dimensions to the current gridWidth and gridHeight");
1794        this.backgrounds = backgrounds;
1795    }
1796
1797    /**
1798     * Gets a direct reference to the TextCellFactory this uses to draw and size its text items and cells.
1799     * @return a direct reference to the TextCellFactory this uses to draw and size its text items and cells.
1800     */
1801    public TextCellFactory getFont() {
1802        return font;
1803    }
1804
1805    /**
1806     * Sets the TextCellFactory this uses to draw and size its text items and cells. The given TextCellFactory must not
1807     * be null. If font is uninitialized, this will initialize it using cellWidth and cellHeight. If font has been
1808     * initialized with a different height and width, then the sizing of this SparseLayers will change.
1809     * @param font a non-null TextCellFactory; if uninitialized, this will initialize it using cellWidth and cellHeight.
1810     */
1811    public void setFont(TextCellFactory font) {
1812        if(font == null)
1813            throw new IllegalArgumentException("SparseLayers.font must not be set to null");
1814        if(!font.initialized())
1815            font.width(cellWidth()).height(cellHeight()).initBySize();
1816        this.font = font;
1817    }
1818
1819    /**
1820     * Gets the IColorCenter for Color objects (almost always a SquidColorCenter, but this isn't guaranteed) that this
1821     * uses to cache and possibly alter Colors that given to it as parameters.
1822     * @return the IColorCenter of Color that this uses to cache and modify Colors given to it
1823     */
1824    public IColorCenter<Color> getScc() {
1825        return scc;
1826    }
1827
1828    /**
1829     * Sets the IColorCenter for Color objects that this uses to cache and modify Colors given to it; does not accept
1830     * null parameters.
1831     * @param scc a non-null IColorCenter of Color that this will use to cache and modify Colors given to it
1832     */
1833    public void setScc(IColorCenter<Color> scc) {
1834        if(scc == null)
1835            throw new IllegalArgumentException("The IColorCenter<Color> given to setScc() must not be null");
1836        this.scc = scc;
1837    }
1838
1839    /**
1840     * Used internally to go between grid positions and world positions.
1841     * @param gridX x on the grid
1842     * @return x in the world
1843     */
1844    public float worldX(int gridX)
1845    {
1846        return getX() + gridX * font.actualCellWidth;
1847    }
1848    /**
1849     * Used internally to go between grid positions and world positions.
1850     * @param gridY y on the grid
1851     * @return y in the world
1852     */
1853    public float worldY(int gridY)
1854    {
1855        return getY() + (gridHeight - gridY) * font.actualCellHeight;
1856    }
1857
1858    /**
1859     * Used internally to go between world positions and grid positions.
1860     * @param worldX x in the world
1861     * @return x on the grid
1862     */
1863    public int gridX(float worldX)
1864    {
1865        return Math.round((worldX - getX()) / font.actualCellWidth);
1866    }
1867
1868    /**
1869     * Used internally to go between world positions and grid positions.
1870     * @param worldY y in the world
1871     * @return y on the grid
1872     */
1873    public int gridY(float worldY)
1874    {
1875        return Math.round((getY() - worldY) / font.actualCellHeight + gridHeight);
1876    }
1877
1878    /**
1879     * Using the existing background color at the position x,y, this performs color blending from that existing color to
1880     * the given color (as a float), using the mixBy parameter to determine how much of the color parameter to use (1f
1881     * will set the color in this to the parameter, while 0f for mixBy will ignore the color parameter entirely).
1882     * @param x the x component of the position in this panel to draw the starting color from
1883     * @param y the y component of the position in this panel to draw the starting color from
1884     * @param color the new color to mix with the starting color; a packed float, as made by {@link Color#toFloatBits()}
1885     * @param mixBy the amount by which the new color will affect the old one, between 0 (no effect) and 1 (overwrite)
1886     */
1887    @Override
1888    public void blend(int x, int y, float color, float mixBy)
1889    {
1890        backgrounds[x][y] = SColor.lerpFloatColorsBlended(backgrounds[x][y], color, mixBy);
1891    }
1892
1893    /**
1894     * Produces a single char with a color, that can be positioned independently of the contents of this SparseLayers.
1895     * Various effects in this class take a Glyph parameter and can perform visual effects with one. This takes a char
1896     * to show, a color that may be filtered, and an x,y position in grid cells, and returns a Glyph that has those
1897     * qualities set.
1898     * @param shown the char to use in the Glyph
1899     * @param color the color to use for the Glyph, which can be filtered
1900     * @param x the x position, in grid cells
1901     * @param y the y position, in grid cells
1902     * @return a Glyph (an inner class of TextCellFactory) with the given qualities
1903     */
1904    public TextCellFactory.Glyph glyph(char shown, Color color, int x, int y)
1905    {
1906        return glyph(shown, color == null ? 0f : scc.filter(color).toFloatBits(), x, y);
1907    }
1908
1909    /**
1910     * Produces a single char with a color, that can be positioned independently of the contents of this SparseLayers.
1911     * Various effects in this class take a Glyph parameter and can perform visual effects with one. This takes a char
1912     * to show, a color as an encoded float, and an x,y position in grid cells, and returns a Glyph that has those
1913     * qualities set.
1914     * @param shown the char to use in the Glyph
1915     * @param color the color to use for the Glyph as an encoded float
1916     * @param x the x position, in grid cells
1917     * @param y the y position, in grid cells
1918     * @return a Glyph (an inner class of TextCellFactory) with the given qualities
1919     */
1920    public TextCellFactory.Glyph glyph(char shown, float color, int x, int y)
1921    {
1922        TextCellFactory.Glyph g =
1923                font.glyph(shown, color,
1924                        worldX(x),
1925                        worldY(y));
1926        glyphs.add(g);
1927        return g;
1928    }
1929    /**
1930     * "Promotes" a colorful char in the first layer to a Glyph that can be positioned independently of the contents of
1931     * this SparseLayers. Various effects in this class take a Glyph parameter and can perform visual effects with one.
1932     * This takes only an x,y position in grid cells, removes the char at that position in the first layer from normal
1933     * rendering, and returns a Glyph at that same position with the same char and color, but that can be moved more.
1934     * @param x the x position, in grid cells
1935     * @param y the y position, in grid cells
1936     * @return a Glyph (an inner class of TextCellFactory) that took the qualities of the removed char and its color
1937     */
1938    public TextCellFactory.Glyph glyphFromGrid(int x, int y)
1939    {
1940        int code = SparseTextMap.encodePosition(x, y);
1941        SparseTextMap stm = layers.get(0);
1942        char shown = stm.getChar(code, ' ');
1943        float color = stm.getFloat(code, 0f);
1944        stm.remove(code);
1945        TextCellFactory.Glyph g =
1946                font.glyph(shown, color, worldX(x), worldY(y));
1947        glyphs.add(g);
1948        return g;
1949    }
1950    /**
1951     * "Promotes" a colorful char in the given layer to a Glyph that can be positioned independently of the contents of
1952     * this SparseLayers. Various effects in this class take a Glyph parameter and can perform visual effects with one.
1953     * This takes only an x,y position in grid cells, removes the char at that position in the given layer from normal
1954     * rendering, and returns a Glyph at that same position with the same char and color, but that can be moved more.
1955     * @param x the x position, in grid cells
1956     * @param y the y position, in grid cells
1957     * @param layer the layer to take a colorful char from
1958     * @return a Glyph (an inner class of TextCellFactory) that took the qualities of the removed char and its color; may return null if the layer is invalid
1959     */
1960    public TextCellFactory.Glyph glyphFromGrid(int x, int y, int layer) {
1961        layer = mapping.get(layer, -1);
1962        if (layer >= 0) {
1963            SparseTextMap stm = layers.get(layer);
1964            int code = SparseTextMap.encodePosition(x, y);
1965            char shown = stm.getChar(code, ' ');
1966            float color = stm.getFloat(code, 0f);
1967            stm.remove(code);
1968            TextCellFactory.Glyph g =
1969                    font.glyph(shown, color, worldX(x), worldY(y));
1970            glyphs.add(g);
1971            return g;
1972        }
1973        else
1974        {
1975            return null;
1976        }
1977    }
1978
1979    /**
1980     * Brings a Glyph back into normal rendering, removing it from the Glyphs this class knows about and filling the
1981     * grid's char at the Glyph's position in the first layer with the Glyph's char and color.
1982     * @param glyph the Glyph to remove and fit back into the grid
1983     */
1984    public void recallToGrid(TextCellFactory.Glyph glyph)
1985    {
1986        layers.get(0).place(gridX(glyph.getY()), gridY(glyph.getY()), glyph.shown, glyph.getPackedColor());
1987        glyphs.remove(glyph);
1988    }
1989
1990    /**
1991     * Brings a Glyph back into normal rendering, removing it from the Glyphs this class knows about and filling the
1992     * grid's char at the Glyph's position in the given layer with the Glyph's char and color.
1993     * @param glyph the Glyph to remove and fit back into the grid
1994     */
1995    public void recallToGrid(TextCellFactory.Glyph glyph, int layer)
1996    {
1997        layer = mapping.get(layer, 0);
1998        layers.get(layer).place(gridX(glyph.getY()), gridY(glyph.getY()), glyph.shown, glyph.getPackedColor());
1999        glyphs.remove(glyph);
2000    }
2001
2002    /**
2003     * A way to remove a Glyph from the group of glyphs this renders, while also ending any animations or other Actions
2004     * that the removed Glyph was scheduled to perform.
2005     * @param glyph a Glyph that should be removed from the {@link #glyphs} List this holds
2006     */
2007    public void removeGlyph(TextCellFactory.Glyph glyph)
2008    {
2009        glyph.clearActions();
2010        glyphs.remove(glyph);
2011    }
2012    /**
2013     * Start a bumping animation in the given direction that will last duration seconds.
2014     * @param glyph
2015     *              A {@link TextCellFactory.Glyph}, probably produced by
2016     *              {@link #glyph(char, float, int, int)} or {@link #glyphFromGrid(int, int)}
2017     * @param direction the direction for the glyph to bump towards
2018     * @param duration a float, measured in seconds, for how long the animation should last; commonly 0.12f
2019     */
2020    public void bump(final TextCellFactory.Glyph glyph, Direction direction, float duration) {
2021        bump(0f, glyph, direction, duration, null);
2022    }
2023    /**
2024     * Start a bumping animation in the given direction after delay seconds, that will last duration seconds; runs
2025     * postRunnable after the duration completes if postRunnable is non-null.
2026     * 
2027     * @param delay how long to wait in seconds before starting the effect
2028     * @param glyph
2029     *              A {@link TextCellFactory.Glyph}, which should be produced by a SparseLayers method like
2030     *              {@link #glyph(char, float, int, int)} or {@link #glyphFromGrid(int, int)}
2031     * @param direction the direction for the glyph to bump towards
2032     * @param duration a float, measured in seconds, for how long the animation should last; commonly 0.12f
2033     * @param postRunnable a Runnable to execute after the bump completes; may be null to do nothing.
2034     */
2035    public void bump(final float delay, final TextCellFactory.Glyph glyph, Direction direction, float duration, final /* @Nullable */ Runnable postRunnable)
2036    {
2037        final float x = glyph.getX(),
2038                y = glyph.getY();
2039        duration = Math.max(0.015f, duration);
2040        final int nbActions = 2 + (0 < delay ? 1 : 0) + (postRunnable == null ? 0 : 1);
2041        int index = 0;
2042        final Action[] sequence = new Action[nbActions];
2043        if (0 < delay)
2044            sequence[index++] = Actions.delay(delay);
2045        sequence[index++] = Actions.moveToAligned(x + direction.deltaX * 0.35f * font.actualCellWidth,
2046                y - direction.deltaY * 0.35f * font.actualCellHeight,
2047                Align.bottomLeft, duration * 0.35F);
2048        sequence[index++] = Actions.moveToAligned(x, y, Align.bottomLeft, duration * 0.65F);
2049        if(postRunnable != null)
2050        {
2051            sequence[index] = Actions.run(postRunnable);
2052        }
2053        glyph.addAction(Actions.sequence(sequence));
2054    }
2055
2056    /**
2057     * Slides {@code glyph} from {@code (xstartX,startY)} to {@code (newx, newy)}.
2058     * Takes a number of seconds equal to duration to complete. This also allows
2059     * a Runnable to be given as {@code postRunnable} to be run after the
2060     * slide completes, or null to not run anything after the slide.
2061     *
2062     * @param glyph
2063     *            A {@link TextCellFactory.Glyph}, probably produced by
2064     *            {@link #glyph(char, float, int, int)} or {@link #glyphFromGrid(int, int)}
2065     * @param startX
2066     *            Where to start the slide, horizontally.
2067     * @param startY
2068     *            Where to start the slide, vertically.
2069     * @param newX
2070     *            Where to end the slide, horizontally.
2071     * @param newY
2072     *            Where to end the slide, vertically.
2073     * @param duration
2074     *            The animation's duration.
2075     * @param postRunnable a Runnable to execute after the slide completes; may be null to do nothing.
2076     */
2077    public void slide(TextCellFactory.Glyph glyph, final int startX, final int startY, final int newX,
2078                      final int newY, float duration, /* @Nullable */ Runnable postRunnable) {
2079        slide(0f, glyph, startX, startY, newX, newY, duration, postRunnable);
2080    }
2081
2082    /**
2083     * Slides {@code glyph} from {@code (xstartX,startY)} to {@code (newx, newy)} after waiting {@code delay} seconds.
2084     * Takes a number of seconds equal to duration to complete (starting after the delay). This also allows
2085     * a Runnable to be given as {@code postRunnable} to be run after the
2086     * slide completes, or null to not run anything after the slide.
2087     *
2088     * @param delay how long to wait in seconds before starting the effect
2089     * @param glyph
2090     *            A {@link TextCellFactory.Glyph}, probably produced by
2091     *            {@link #glyph(char, float, int, int)} or {@link #glyphFromGrid(int, int)}
2092     * @param startX
2093     *            Where to start the slide, horizontally.
2094     * @param startY
2095     *            Where to start the slide, vertically.
2096     * @param newX
2097     *            Where to end the slide, horizontally.
2098     * @param newY
2099     *            Where to end the slide, vertically.
2100     * @param duration
2101     *            The animation's duration.
2102     * @param postRunnable a Runnable to execute after the slide completes; may be null to do nothing.
2103     */
2104    public void slide(float delay, TextCellFactory.Glyph glyph, final int startX, final int startY, final int newX,
2105                      final int newY, float duration, /* @Nullable */ Runnable postRunnable) {
2106        glyph.setPosition(worldX(startX), worldY(startY));
2107        duration = Math.max(0.015f, duration);
2108        final int nbActions = 1 + (0 < delay ? 1 : 0) + (postRunnable == null ? 0 : 1);
2109        int index = 0;
2110        final Action[] sequence = new Action[nbActions];
2111        if (0 < delay)
2112            sequence[index++] = Actions.delay(delay);
2113        final float nextX = worldX(newX);
2114        final float nextY = worldY(newY);
2115        sequence[index++] = Actions.moveToAligned(nextX, nextY, Align.bottomLeft, duration);
2116        if(postRunnable != null)
2117        {
2118            sequence[index] = Actions.run(postRunnable);
2119        }
2120
2121        glyph.addAction(Actions.sequence(sequence));
2122    }
2123
2124    /**
2125     * Starts an wiggling animation for the object at the given location for the given duration in seconds.
2126     *
2127     * @param glyph
2128     *            A {@link TextCellFactory.Glyph}, probably produced by
2129     *            {@link #glyph(char, float, int, int)} or {@link #glyphFromGrid(int, int)}
2130     * @param duration in seconds, as a float
2131     */
2132    public void wiggle(final TextCellFactory.Glyph glyph, float duration) {
2133        wiggle(0f, glyph, duration, null);
2134    }
2135
2136    /**
2137     * Starts a wiggling animation for the object at the given location, after waiting delay seconds, for the given
2138     * duration in seconds; runs postRunnable afterwards if it is non-null.
2139     *
2140     * @param delay how long to wait in seconds before starting the effect
2141     * @param glyph
2142     *            A {@link TextCellFactory.Glyph}, probably produced by
2143     *            {@link #glyph(char, float, int, int)} or {@link #glyphFromGrid(int, int)}
2144     * @param duration in seconds, as a float
2145     * @param postRunnable a Runnable to execute after the wiggle completes; may be null to do nothing.
2146     */
2147    public void wiggle(final float delay, final TextCellFactory.Glyph glyph, float duration,
2148            /* @Nullable */ Runnable postRunnable) {
2149        final float x = glyph.getX(), y = glyph.getY(),
2150                cellWidth = font.actualCellWidth, cellHeight = font.actualCellHeight;
2151        duration = Math.max(0.015f, duration);
2152        final int nbActions = 5 + (0 < delay ? 1 : 0) + (postRunnable == null ? 0 : 1);
2153        final Action[] sequence = new Action[nbActions];
2154        int index = 0;
2155        if (0 < delay)
2156            sequence[index++] = Actions.delay(delay);
2157        final StatefulRNG gRandom = DefaultResources.getGuiRandom();
2158        sequence[index++] = Actions.moveToAligned(x + (gRandom.nextFloat() - 0.5F) * cellWidth * 0.4f,
2159                y + (gRandom.nextFloat() - 0.5F) * cellHeight * 0.4f, Align.bottomLeft, duration * 0.2F);
2160        sequence[index++] = Actions.moveToAligned(x + (gRandom.nextFloat() - 0.5F) * cellWidth * 0.4f,
2161                y + (gRandom.nextFloat() - 0.5F) * cellHeight * 0.4f, Align.bottomLeft, duration * 0.2F);
2162        sequence[index++] = Actions.moveToAligned(x + (gRandom.nextFloat() - 0.5F) * cellWidth * 0.4f,
2163                y + (gRandom.nextFloat() - 0.5F) * cellHeight * 0.4f, Align.bottomLeft, duration * 0.2F);
2164        sequence[index++] = Actions.moveToAligned(x + (gRandom.nextFloat() - 0.5F) * cellWidth * 0.4f,
2165                y + (gRandom.nextFloat() - 0.5F) * cellHeight * 0.4f, Align.bottomLeft, duration * 0.2F);
2166        sequence[index++] = Actions.moveToAligned(x, y, Align.bottomLeft, duration * 0.2F);
2167        if(postRunnable != null)
2168        {
2169            sequence[index] = Actions.run(postRunnable);
2170        }
2171        glyph.addAction(Actions.sequence(sequence));
2172    }
2173    /**
2174     * Tints the background at position x,y so it becomes the given encodedColor, then after the tint is complete it 
2175     * returns the cell to its original color, taking duration seconds.
2176     * <br>
2177     * This will only behave correctly if you call {@link Stage#act()} before you call {@link Stage#draw()}, but after
2178     * any changes to the contents of this SparseLayers. If you change the contents, then draw, and then act, that will
2179     * draw the contents without the tint this applies, then apply the tint when you call act(), then quickly overwrite
2180     * the tint in the next frame. That visually appears as nothing happening other than a delay.
2181     * @param x the x-coordinate of the cell to tint
2182     * @param y the y-coordinate of the cell to tint
2183     * @param color what to transition the cell's color towards, and then transition back from, as a Color object
2184     * @param duration how long the total "round-trip" transition should take in seconds
2185     */
2186    public void tint(final int x, final int y, final Color color, float duration) {
2187        tint(0f, x, y, color.toFloatBits(), duration, null);
2188    }
2189    /**
2190     * Tints the background at position x,y so it becomes the given encodedColor, then after the tint is complete it 
2191     * returns the cell to its original color, taking duration seconds.
2192     * <br>
2193     * This will only behave correctly if you call {@link Stage#act()} before you call {@link Stage#draw()}, but after
2194     * any changes to the contents of this SparseLayers. If you change the contents, then draw, and then act, that will
2195     * draw the contents without the tint this applies, then apply the tint when you call act(), then quickly overwrite
2196     * the tint in the next frame. That visually appears as nothing happening other than a delay.
2197     * @param x the x-coordinate of the cell to tint
2198     * @param y the y-coordinate of the cell to tint
2199     * @param encodedColor what to transition the cell's color towards, and then transition back from, as a packed float
2200     * @param duration how long the total "round-trip" transition should take in seconds
2201     */
2202    public void tint(final int x, final int y, final float encodedColor, float duration) {
2203        tint(0f, x, y, encodedColor, duration, null);
2204    }
2205    /**
2206     * Tints the background at position x,y so it becomes the given encodedColor, waiting for {@code delay} (in seconds)
2207     * before performing it, then after the tint is complete it returns the cell to its original color, taking duration
2208     * seconds. Additionally, enqueue {@code postRunnable} for running after the created action ends.
2209     * <br>
2210     * This will only behave correctly if you call {@link Stage#act()} before you call {@link Stage#draw()}, but after
2211     * any changes to the contents of this SparseLayers. If you change the contents, then draw, and then act, that will
2212     * draw the contents without the tint this applies, then apply the tint when you call act(), then quickly overwrite
2213     * the tint in the next frame. That visually appears as nothing happening other than a delay.
2214     * @param delay how long to wait in seconds before starting the effect
2215     * @param x the x-coordinate of the cell to tint
2216     * @param y the y-coordinate of the cell to tint
2217     * @param encodedColor what to transition the cell's color towards, and then transition back from, as a packed float
2218     * @param duration how long the total "round-trip" transition should take in seconds
2219     * @param postRunnable a Runnable to execute after the tint completes; may be null to do nothing.
2220     */
2221    public void tint(final float delay, final int x, final int y, final float encodedColor, float duration,
2222            /* @Nullable */ Runnable postRunnable) {
2223        if(x < 0 || x >= gridWidth || y < 0 || y >= gridHeight)
2224            return;
2225        duration = Math.max(0.015f, duration);
2226        final float ac = backgrounds[x][y];
2227        final int nbActions = 3 + (0 < delay ? 1 : 0) + (postRunnable == null ? 0 : 1);
2228        final Action[] sequence = new Action[nbActions];
2229        int index = 0;
2230        if (0 < delay)
2231            sequence[index++] = Actions.delay(delay);
2232        sequence[index++] = new TemporalAction(duration * 0.3f) {
2233            @Override
2234            protected void update(float percent) {
2235                backgrounds[x][y] = SColor.lerpFloatColors(ac, encodedColor, percent);
2236            }
2237        };
2238        sequence[index++] = new TemporalAction(duration * 0.7f) {
2239            @Override
2240            protected void update(float percent) {
2241                backgrounds[x][y] = SColor.lerpFloatColors(encodedColor, ac, percent);
2242            }
2243        };
2244        if(postRunnable != null)
2245        {
2246            sequence[index++] = Actions.run(postRunnable);
2247        }
2248        sequence[index] = Actions.delay(duration, Actions.run(new Runnable() {
2249            @Override
2250            public void run() {
2251                backgrounds[x][y] = ac;
2252            }
2253        }));
2254
2255        addAction(Actions.sequence(sequence));
2256    }
2257
2258    /**
2259     * Tints the foreground in the given layer at position x,y so it becomes the given encodedColor, then after the tint
2260     * is complete it returns the cell to its original color, taking duration seconds.
2261     * <br>
2262     * The {@link SquidPanel#tint(float, int, int, Color, float, Runnable)} method has been reworked to use the same
2263     * technique this class uses for rendering text, and the two classes should have similar appearance (if not the
2264     * same) when rendering the same text. SparseLayers tends to be faster, especially when not all of the map is shown.
2265     * <br>
2266     * This will only behave correctly if you call {@link Stage#act()} before you call {@link Stage#draw()}, but after
2267     * any changes to the contents of this SparseLayers. If you change the contents, then draw, and then act, that will
2268     * draw the contents without the tint this applies, then apply the tint when you call act(), then quickly overwrite
2269     * the tint in the next frame. That visually appears as nothing happening other than a delay.
2270     * @param x the x-coordinate of the cell to tint
2271     * @param y the y-coordinate of the cell to tint
2272     * @param layer which layer to affect; if you haven't specified a layer when placing text, then this should be 0
2273     * @param color what to transition the cell's color towards, and then transition back from, as a Color object
2274     * @param duration how long the total "round-trip" transition should take in seconds
2275     */
2276    public void tint(final int x, final int y, final int layer, final Color color, float duration) {
2277        tint(0f, x, y, layer, color.toFloatBits(), duration, null);
2278    }
2279
2280    /**
2281     * Tints the foreground in the given layer at position x,y so it becomes the given encodedColor, then after the tint
2282     * is complete it returns the cell to its original color, taking duration seconds.
2283     * <br>
2284     * The {@link SquidPanel#tint(float, int, int, Color, float, Runnable)} method has been reworked to use the same
2285     * technique this class uses for rendering text, and the two classes should have similar appearance (if not the
2286     * same) when rendering the same text. SparseLayers tends to be faster, especially when not all of the map is shown.
2287     * <br>
2288     * This will only behave correctly if you call {@link Stage#act()} before you call {@link Stage#draw()}, but after
2289     * any changes to the contents of this SparseLayers. If you change the contents, then draw, and then act, that will
2290     * draw the contents without the tint this applies, then apply the tint when you call act(), then quickly overwrite
2291     * the tint in the next frame. That visually appears as nothing happening other than a delay.
2292     * @param x the x-coordinate of the cell to tint
2293     * @param y the y-coordinate of the cell to tint
2294     * @param layer which layer to affect; if you haven't specified a layer when placing text, then this should be 0
2295     * @param encodedColor what to transition the cell's color towards, and then transition back from, as a packed float
2296     * @param duration how long the total "round-trip" transition should take in seconds
2297     */
2298    public void tint(final int x, final int y, final int layer, final float encodedColor, float duration) {
2299        tint(0f, x, y, layer, encodedColor, duration, null);
2300    }
2301    /**
2302     * Tints the foreground in the given layer at position x,y so it becomes the given encodedColor, waiting for
2303     * {@code delay} (in seconds) before performing it, then after the tint is complete it returns the cell to its
2304     * original color, taking duration seconds. Additionally, enqueue {@code postRunnable} for running after the created
2305     * action ends.
2306     * <br>
2307     * The {@link SquidPanel#tint(float, int, int, Color, float, Runnable)} method has been reworked to use the same
2308     * technique this class uses for rendering text, and the two classes should have similar appearance (if not the
2309     * same) when rendering the same text. SparseLayers tends to be faster, especially when not all of the map is shown.
2310     * <br>
2311     * This will only behave correctly if you call {@link Stage#act()} before you call {@link Stage#draw()}, but after
2312     * any changes to the contents of this SparseLayers. If you change the contents, then draw, and then act, that will
2313     * draw the contents without the tint this applies, then apply the tint when you call act(), then quickly overwrite
2314     * the tint in the next frame. That visually appears as nothing happening other than a delay.
2315     * @param delay how long to wait in seconds before starting the effect
2316     * @param x the x-coordinate of the cell to tint
2317     * @param y the y-coordinate of the cell to tint
2318     * @param layer which layer to affect; if you haven't specified a layer when placing text, then this should be 0
2319     * @param encodedColor what to transition the cell's color towards, and then transition back from, as a packed float
2320     * @param duration how long the total "round-trip" transition should take in seconds
2321     * @param postRunnable a Runnable to execute after the tint completes; may be null to do nothing.
2322     */
2323    public void tint(final float delay, final int x, final int y, final int layer, final float encodedColor, float duration,
2324            /* @Nullable */ Runnable postRunnable) {
2325        if(x < 0 || x >= gridWidth || y < 0 || y >= gridHeight || layer < 0 || layer >= layers.size())
2326            return;
2327        final SparseTextMap l = layers.get(layer);
2328        duration = Math.max(0.015f, duration);
2329        final int pos = SparseTextMap.encodePosition(x, y);
2330        final float ac = l.getFloat(pos,0f);
2331        final int nbActions = 3 + (0 < delay ? 1 : 0) + (postRunnable == null ? 0 : 1);
2332        final Action[] sequence = new Action[nbActions];
2333        int index = 0;
2334        if (0 < delay)
2335            sequence[index++] = Actions.delay(delay);
2336        sequence[index++] = new TemporalAction(duration * 0.3f) {
2337            @Override
2338            protected void update(float percent) {
2339                l.updateFloat(pos, SColor.lerpFloatColors(ac, encodedColor, percent));
2340            }
2341        };
2342        sequence[index++] = new TemporalAction(duration * 0.7f) {
2343            @Override
2344            protected void update(float percent) {
2345                l.updateFloat(pos, SColor.lerpFloatColors(encodedColor, ac, percent));
2346            }
2347        };
2348        if(postRunnable != null)
2349        {
2350            sequence[index++] = Actions.run(postRunnable);
2351        }
2352        /* Do this one last, so that hasActiveAnimations() returns true during 'postRunnables' */
2353        sequence[index] = Actions.delay(duration, Actions.run(new Runnable() {
2354            @Override
2355            public void run() {
2356                l.updateFloat(pos, ac);
2357            }
2358        }));
2359        addAction(Actions.sequence(sequence));
2360    }
2361    /**
2362     * Tints the given glyph (which may or may not be part of the {@link #glyphs} list this holds) so it becomes the
2363     * given encodedColor, then after the tint is complete it returns the cell to its original color, taking duration
2364     * seconds. This resets the glyph to its pre-tint color before it ends.
2365     * @param glyph the {@link TextCellFactory.Glyph} to tint
2366     * @param encodedColor what to transition the cell's color towards, and then transition back from, as a packed float
2367     * @param duration how long the total "round-trip" transition should take in seconds
2368     */
2369    public void tint(final TextCellFactory.Glyph glyph, final float encodedColor, float duration) {
2370        tint(0f, glyph, encodedColor, duration, null);
2371    }
2372    /**
2373     * Tints the given glyph (which may or may not be part of the {@link #glyphs} list this holds) so it becomes the
2374     * given encodedColor, waiting for {@code delay} (in seconds) before performing it, then after the tint is complete
2375     * it returns the cell to its original color, taking duration seconds. Additionally, enqueue {@code postRunnable}
2376     * for running after the created action ends. This resets the glyph to its pre-tint color before it runs any
2377     * {@code postRunnable}.
2378     * @param delay how long to wait in seconds before starting the effect
2379     * @param glyph the {@link TextCellFactory.Glyph} to tint
2380     * @param encodedColor what to transition the cell's color towards, and then transition back from, as a packed float
2381     * @param duration how long the total "round-trip" transition should take in seconds
2382     * @param postRunnable a Runnable to execute after the tint completes; may be null to do nothing.
2383     */
2384    public void tint(float delay, final TextCellFactory.Glyph glyph, final float encodedColor, float duration,
2385            /* @Nullable */ Runnable postRunnable) {
2386        duration = Math.max(0.015f, duration);
2387        final float ac = glyph.getPackedColor();
2388        final int nbActions = 3 + (0 < delay ? 1 : 0) + (postRunnable == null ? 0 : 1);
2389        final Action[] sequence = new Action[nbActions];
2390        int index = 0;
2391        if (0 < delay)
2392            sequence[index++] = Actions.delay(delay);
2393        sequence[index++] = new TemporalAction(duration * 0.3f) {
2394            @Override
2395            protected void update(float percent) {
2396                glyph.setPackedColor(SColor.lerpFloatColors(ac, encodedColor, percent));
2397            }
2398        };
2399        sequence[index++] = new TemporalAction(duration * 0.7f) {
2400            @Override
2401            protected void update(float percent) {
2402                glyph.setPackedColor(SColor.lerpFloatColors(encodedColor, ac, percent));
2403            }
2404        };
2405        if(postRunnable != null)
2406        {
2407            sequence[index++] = Actions.run(postRunnable);
2408        }
2409        /* Do this one last, so that hasActiveAnimations() returns true during 'postRunnables' */
2410        sequence[index] = Actions.delay(duration, Actions.run(new Runnable() {
2411            @Override
2412            public void run() {
2413                glyph.setPackedColor(ac);
2414            }
2415        }));
2416        addAction(Actions.sequence(sequence));
2417    }
2418    /**
2419     * Create a new Glyph at (startX, startY) using the char shown with the given startColor, and immediately starts
2420     * changing color to endColor, changing position so it ends on the cell (endX, endY), taking duration seconds to
2421     * complete before removing the Glyph.
2422     * <br>
2423     * Unlike {@link SquidPanel#summon(float, int, int, int, int, char, Color, Color, boolean, float, float, float)},
2424     * this does not rotate the Glyph it produces.
2425     * @param startX the starting x position in cells
2426     * @param startY the starting y position in cells
2427     * @param endX the ending x position in cells
2428     * @param endY the ending y position in cells
2429     * @param shown the char to show (the same char throughout the effect)
2430     * @param startColor the starting Color
2431     * @param endColor the Color to transition to
2432     * @param duration the duration in seconds for the effect
2433     */
2434    public void summon(int startX, int startY, int endX, int endY, char shown,
2435                       final float startColor, final float endColor, float duration)
2436    {
2437        summon(0f, startX, startY, endX, endY, shown, startColor, endColor, duration, null);
2438    }
2439    /**
2440     * Create a new Glyph at (startX, startY) using the char shown with the given startColor, and after delay seconds,
2441     * starts changing color to endColor, changing position so it ends on the cell (endX, endY), taking duration seconds
2442     * to complete before running postRunnable (if it is non-null) and finally removing the Glyph.
2443     * <br>
2444     * Unlike {@link SquidPanel#summon(float, int, int, int, int, char, Color, Color, boolean, float, float, float)},
2445     * this does not rotate the Glyph it produces.
2446     * @param delay how long to wait in seconds before starting the effect
2447     * @param startX the starting x position in cells
2448     * @param startY the starting y position in cells
2449     * @param endX the ending x position in cells
2450     * @param endY the ending y position in cells
2451     * @param shown the char to show (the same char throughout the effect)
2452     * @param startColor the starting Color
2453     * @param endColor the Color to transition to
2454     * @param duration the duration in seconds for the effect
2455     * @param postRunnable a Runnable to execute after the summon completes; may be null to do nothing.
2456     */
2457    public void summon(float delay, int startX, int startY, int endX, int endY, char shown,
2458                       final float startColor, final float endColor, float duration,
2459            /* @Nullable */ Runnable postRunnable)
2460    {
2461        duration = Math.max(0.015f, duration);
2462        final int nbActions = 2 + (0 < delay ? 1 : 0) + (postRunnable == null ? 0 : 1);
2463        int index = 0;
2464        final Action[] sequence = new Action[nbActions];
2465        if (0 < delay)
2466            sequence[index++] = Actions.delay(delay);
2467        final TextCellFactory.Glyph glyph = glyph(shown, startColor, startX, startY);
2468        sequence[index++] = Actions.parallel(
2469                new TemporalAction(duration) {
2470                    @Override
2471                    protected void update(float percent) {
2472                        glyph.setPackedColor(SColor.lerpFloatColors(startColor, endColor, percent * 0.95f));
2473                    }
2474                },
2475                Actions.moveTo(worldX(endX), worldY(endY), duration));
2476        if(postRunnable != null)
2477        {
2478            sequence[index++] = Actions.run(postRunnable);
2479        }
2480        /* Do this one last, so that hasActiveAnimations() returns true during 'postRunnables' */
2481        sequence[index] = Actions.run(new Runnable() {
2482            @Override
2483            public void run() {
2484                glyphs.remove(glyph);
2485            }
2486        });
2487        glyph.addAction(Actions.sequence(sequence));
2488    }
2489
2490    /**
2491     * Create a new Glyph at (startX, startY) in world coordinates (often pixels on the screen) using the char shown
2492     * with the given startColor, and immediately starts changing color to endColor, changing position so it ends at the
2493     * world coordinates (endX, endY), taking duration seconds to complete before removing the Glyph.
2494     * <br>
2495     * Unlike {@link SquidPanel#summon(float, int, int, int, int, char, Color, Color, boolean, float, float, float)},
2496     * this does not rotate the Glyph it produces.
2497     * @param startX the starting x position in world coordinates
2498     * @param startY the starting y position in world coordinates
2499     * @param endX the ending x position in world coordinates
2500     * @param endY the ending y position in world coordinates
2501     * @param shown the char to show (the same char throughout the effect)
2502     * @param startColor the starting Color
2503     * @param endColor the Color to transition to
2504     * @param duration the duration in seconds for the effect
2505     */
2506    public void summon(float startX, float startY, float endX, float endY, char shown,
2507                       final float startColor, final float endColor, float duration)
2508    {
2509        summon(0f, startX, startY, endX, endY, shown, startColor, endColor, duration, null);
2510    }
2511    /**
2512     * Create a new Glyph at (startX, startY) in world coordinates (often pixels on the screen) using the char shown
2513     * with the given startColor, and after delay seconds, starts changing color to endColor, changing position so it
2514     * ends at the world coordinates (endX, endY), taking duration seconds to complete before running postRunnable (if
2515     * it is non-null) and finally removing the Glyph.
2516     * <br>
2517     * Unlike {@link SquidPanel#summon(float, int, int, int, int, char, Color, Color, boolean, float, float, float)},
2518     * this does not rotate the Glyph it produces.
2519     * @param delay how long to wait in seconds before starting the effect
2520     * @param startX the starting x position in world coordinates
2521     * @param startY the starting y position in world coordinates
2522     * @param endX the ending x position in world coordinates
2523     * @param endY the ending y position in world coordinates
2524     * @param shown the char to show (the same char throughout the effect)
2525     * @param startColor the starting Color
2526     * @param endColor the Color to transition to
2527     * @param duration the duration in seconds for the effect
2528     * @param postRunnable a Runnable to execute after the summon completes; may be null to do nothing.
2529     */
2530    public void summon(float delay, float startX, float startY, float endX, float endY, char shown,
2531                       final float startColor, final float endColor, float duration,
2532            /* @Nullable */ Runnable postRunnable)
2533    {
2534        duration = Math.max(0.015f, duration);
2535        final int nbActions = 2 + (0 < delay ? 1 : 0) + (postRunnable == null ? 0 : 1);
2536        int index = 0;
2537        final Action[] sequence = new Action[nbActions];
2538        if (0 < delay)
2539            sequence[index++] = Actions.delay(delay);
2540        final TextCellFactory.Glyph glyph = glyph(shown, startColor, gridX(startX), gridY(startY));
2541        sequence[index++] = Actions.parallel(
2542                new TemporalAction(duration) {
2543                    @Override
2544                    protected void update(float percent) {
2545                        glyph.setPackedColor(SColor.lerpFloatColors(startColor, endColor, percent * 0.95f));
2546                    }
2547                },
2548                Actions.moveTo(endX, endY, duration));
2549        if(postRunnable != null)
2550        {
2551            sequence[index++] = Actions.run(postRunnable);
2552        }
2553        /* Do this one last, so that hasActiveAnimations() returns true during 'postRunnables' */
2554        sequence[index] = Actions.run(new Runnable() {
2555            @Override
2556            public void run() {
2557                glyphs.remove(glyph);
2558            }
2559        });
2560        glyph.addAction(Actions.sequence(sequence));
2561    }
2562
2563
2564    /**
2565     * Convenience method to produce an explosion, splash, or burst effect. Calls
2566     * {@link #summon(int, int, int, int, char, float, float, float)} repeatedly with
2567     * different parameters. As with summon(), this creates temporary Glyphs that change color and position.
2568     * The distance is how many cells away to move the created Actors away from (x,y). The measurement determines
2569     * whether this produces Glyphs in 4 (cardinal) directions for DIAMOND or OCTAHEDRON, or 8 (cardinal and diagonal)
2570     * directions for any other enum value for Radius; CIRCLE and SPHERE will position the 8 glyphs in a circle, while
2571     * SQUARE and CUBE will position their 8 glyphs in a square.
2572     * <br>
2573     * Unlike {@link SquidPanel#burst(float, int, int, int, boolean, char, Color, Color, boolean, float, float)}, this
2574     * does not rotate the individual Glyphs it produces.
2575     * @param x the starting, center, x-position in cells to create all Actors at
2576     * @param y the starting, center, y-position in cells to create all Actors at
2577     * @param distance how far away, in cells, to move each actor from the center (Chebyshev distance, forming a square)
2578     * @param measurement a Radius enum that determines if 4 (DIAMOND, OCTAHEDRON) or 8 (anything else) Glyphs are
2579     *                    created, and the shape they will take
2580     * @param shown the char to use for Glyphs; should definitely be visible
2581     * @param startColor the encoded color to start the effect with
2582     * @param endColor the encoded color to end the effect on
2583     * @param duration how long, in seconds, the effect should last
2584     */
2585    public void burst(int x, int y, int distance, Radius measurement, char shown,
2586                      float startColor, float endColor, float duration) {
2587        burst(0f, x, y, distance, measurement, shown, startColor, endColor, duration, null);
2588    }
2589    /**
2590     * Convenience method to produce an explosion, splash, or burst effect. Calls
2591     * {@link #summon(float, int, int, int, int, char, float, float, float, Runnable)} repeatedly with
2592     * different parameters. As with summon(), this creates temporary Glyphs that change color and position.
2593     * The distance is how many cells away to move the created Actors away from (x,y). The measurement determines
2594     * whether this produces Glyphs in 4 (cardinal) directions for DIAMOND or OCTAHEDRON, or 8 (cardinal and diagonal)
2595     * directions for any other enum value for Radius; CIRCLE and SPHERE will position the 8 glyphs in a circle, while
2596     * SQUARE and CUBE will position their 8 glyphs in a square. This takes a delay in seconds that can be used to make
2597     * the effect wait to start for some amount of time, and a Runnable that will be run once after the burst's full
2598     * duration completes (not once per summoned Glyph).
2599     * <br>
2600     * Unlike {@link SquidPanel#burst(float, int, int, int, boolean, char, Color, Color, boolean, float, float)}, this
2601     * does not rotate the individual Glyphs it produces.
2602     * @param delay how long to wait in seconds before starting the effect
2603     * @param x the starting, center, x-position in cells to create all Actors at
2604     * @param y the starting, center, y-position in cells to create all Actors at
2605     * @param distance how far away, in cells, to move each actor from the center (Chebyshev distance, forming a square)
2606     * @param measurement a Radius enum that determines if 4 (DIAMOND, OCTAHEDRON) or 8 (anything else) Glyphs are
2607     *                    created, and the shape they will take
2608     * @param shown the char to use for Glyphs; should definitely be visible
2609     * @param startColor the encoded color to start the effect with
2610     * @param endColor the encoded color to end the effect on
2611     * @param duration how long, in seconds, the effect should last
2612     * @param postRunnable a Runnable to execute after the burst completes; may be null to do nothing,
2613     *                     and will only be run once for the whole burst effect.
2614     */
2615    public void burst(float delay, int x, int y, int distance, Radius measurement, char shown,
2616                      float startColor, float endColor, float duration, /* @Nullable */ Runnable postRunnable)
2617    {
2618        Direction d;
2619        switch (measurement)
2620        {
2621            case SQUARE:
2622            case CUBE:
2623                for (int i = 0; i < 7; i++) {
2624                    d = Direction.CLOCKWISE[i];
2625                    summon(delay, x, y, x - d.deltaX * distance, y + d.deltaY * distance,
2626                            shown, startColor, endColor, duration, null);
2627                }
2628                d = Direction.CLOCKWISE[7];
2629                summon(delay, x, y, x - d.deltaX * distance, y + d.deltaY * distance,
2630                        shown, startColor, endColor, duration, postRunnable);
2631                break;
2632            case CIRCLE:
2633            case SPHERE:
2634                float xf = worldX(x), yf = worldY(y);
2635                for (int i = 0; i < 4; i++) {
2636                    d = Direction.DIAGONALS[i];
2637                    summon(delay, xf, yf, xf - d.deltaX * font.actualCellWidth * distance * 0.7071067811865475f, // the constant is 1.0 / Math.sqrt(2.0)
2638                            yf + d.deltaY * font.actualCellHeight * distance * 0.7071067811865475f,
2639                            shown, startColor, endColor, duration, null);
2640                }
2641                // break intentionally absent
2642            default:
2643                for (int i = 0; i < 3; i++) {
2644                    d = Direction.CARDINALS_CLOCKWISE[i];
2645                    summon(delay, x, y, x - d.deltaX * distance, y + d.deltaY * distance,
2646                            shown, startColor, endColor, duration, null);
2647                }
2648                d = Direction.CARDINALS_CLOCKWISE[3];
2649                summon(delay, x, y, x - d.deltaX * distance, y + d.deltaY * distance,
2650                        shown, startColor, endColor, duration, postRunnable);
2651                break;
2652        }
2653    }
2654    /**
2655     * Convenience method to produce an explosion, splash, or burst effect. Calls
2656     * {@link #summon(int, int, int, int, char, float, float, float)} repeatedly with
2657     * different parameters. As with summon(), this creates temporary Glyphs that change color and position.
2658     * The distance is how many cells away to move the created Actors away from (x,y). The measurement determines
2659     * whether this produces Glyphs in 4 (cardinal) directions for DIAMOND or OCTAHEDRON, or 8 (cardinal and diagonal)
2660     * directions for any other enum value for Radius; CIRCLE and SPHERE will position the 8 glyphs in a circle, while
2661     * SQUARE and CUBE will position their 8 glyphs in a square.
2662     * <br>
2663     * Unlike {@link SquidPanel#burst(float, int, int, int, boolean, char, Color, Color, boolean, float, float)}, this
2664     * does not rotate the individual Glyphs it produces.
2665     * @param x the starting, center, x-position in cells to create all Actors at
2666     * @param y the starting, center, y-position in cells to create all Actors at
2667     * @param distance how far away, in cells, to move each actor from the center (Chebyshev distance, forming a square)
2668     * @param measurement a Radius enum that determines if 4 (DIAMOND, OCTAHEDRON) or 8 (anything else) Glyphs are
2669     *                    created, and the shape they will take
2670     * @param choices a String or other CharSequence containing the chars this can randomly choose
2671     * @param startColor the encoded color to start the effect with
2672     * @param endColor the encoded color to end the effect on
2673     * @param duration how long, in seconds, the effect should last
2674     */
2675    public void burst(int x, int y, int distance, Radius measurement, CharSequence choices,
2676                      float startColor, float endColor, float duration) {
2677        burst(0f, x, y, distance, measurement, choices, startColor, endColor, duration, null);
2678    }
2679    /**
2680     * Convenience method to produce an explosion, splash, or burst effect. Calls
2681     * {@link #summon(int, int, int, int, char, float, float, float)} repeatedly with
2682     * different parameters. As with summon(), this creates temporary Glyphs that change color and position.
2683     * The distance is how many cells away to move the created Actors away from (x,y). The measurement determines
2684     * whether this produces Glyphs in 4 (cardinal) directions for DIAMOND or OCTAHEDRON, or 8 (cardinal and diagonal)
2685     * directions for any other enum value for Radius; CIRCLE and SPHERE will position the 8 glyphs in a circle, while
2686     * SQUARE and CUBE will position their 8 glyphs in a square. This takes a delay in seconds that can be used to make
2687     * the effect wait to start for some amount of time, and a Runnable that will be run once after the burst's full
2688     * duration completes (not once per summoned Glyph).
2689     * <br>
2690     * Unlike {@link SquidPanel#burst(float, int, int, int, boolean, char, Color, Color, boolean, float, float)}, this
2691     * does not rotate the individual Glyphs it produces.
2692     * @param delay how long to wait in seconds before starting the effect
2693     * @param x the starting, center, x-position in cells to create all Actors at
2694     * @param y the starting, center, y-position in cells to create all Actors at
2695     * @param distance how far away, in cells, to move each actor from the center (Chebyshev distance, forming a square)
2696     * @param measurement a Radius enum that determines if 4 (DIAMOND, OCTAHEDRON) or 8 (anything else) Glyphs are
2697     *                    created, and the shape they will take
2698     * @param choices a String or other CharSequence containing the chars this can randomly choose
2699     * @param startColor the encoded color to start the effect with
2700     * @param endColor the encoded color to end the effect on
2701     * @param duration how long, in seconds, the effect should last
2702     * @param postRunnable a Runnable to execute after the burst completes; may be null to do nothing,
2703     *                     and will only be run once for the whole burst effect.
2704     */
2705    public void burst(float delay, int x, int y, int distance, Radius measurement, CharSequence choices,
2706                      float startColor, float endColor, float duration, /* @Nullable */ Runnable postRunnable)
2707    {
2708        Direction d;
2709        final int len = choices.length();
2710        final StatefulRNG rng = DefaultResources.getGuiRandom();
2711        switch (measurement)
2712        {
2713            case SQUARE:
2714            case CUBE:
2715                for (int i = 0; i < 7; i++) {
2716                    d = Direction.CLOCKWISE[i];
2717                    summon(delay, x, y, x - d.deltaX * distance, y + d.deltaY * distance,
2718                            choices.charAt(rng.nextIntHasty(len)), startColor, endColor, duration, null);
2719                }
2720                d = Direction.CLOCKWISE[7];
2721                summon(delay, x, y, x - d.deltaX * distance, y + d.deltaY * distance,
2722                        choices.charAt(rng.nextIntHasty(len)), startColor, endColor, duration, postRunnable);
2723
2724                break;
2725            case CIRCLE:
2726            case SPHERE:
2727                float xf = worldX(x), yf = worldY(y);
2728                for (int i = 0; i < 4; i++) {
2729                    d = Direction.DIAGONALS[i];
2730                    summon(delay, xf, yf, xf - d.deltaX * font.actualCellWidth * distance * 0.7071067811865475f,
2731                            yf + d.deltaY * font.actualCellHeight * distance * 0.7071067811865475f,
2732                            choices.charAt(rng.nextIntHasty(len)), startColor, endColor, duration, null);
2733                }
2734                // break intentionally absent
2735            default:
2736                for (int i = 0; i < 3; i++) {
2737                    d = Direction.CARDINALS_CLOCKWISE[i];
2738                    summon(delay, x, y, x - d.deltaX * distance, y + d.deltaY * distance,
2739                            choices.charAt(rng.nextIntHasty(len)), startColor, endColor, duration, null);
2740                }
2741                d = Direction.CARDINALS_CLOCKWISE[3];
2742                summon(delay, x, y, x - d.deltaX * distance, y + d.deltaY * distance,
2743                        choices.charAt(rng.nextIntHasty(len)), startColor, endColor, duration, postRunnable);
2744
2745                break;
2746        }
2747    }
2748
2749    /**
2750     * Changes the background at position x,y so it becomes the given color, taking duration seconds. The
2751     * background will keep the changed color after the effect, unless drawn over.
2752     * <br>
2753     * This will only behave correctly if you call {@link Stage#act()} before you call {@link Stage#draw()}, but after
2754     * any changes to the contents of this SparseLayers. If you change the contents, then draw, and then act, that will
2755     * draw the contents without the recolor this applies, then apply the recolor when you call act(), then quickly
2756     * overwrite the recolor in the next frame. That visually appears as nothing happening other than a delay.
2757     * @param x the x-coordinate of the cell to recolor
2758     * @param y the y-coordinate of the cell to recolor
2759     * @param color what to gradually change the cell's color to, as a Color object
2760     * @param duration how long the total transition should take in seconds
2761     */
2762    public void recolor(final int x, final int y, final Color color, float duration) {
2763        recolor(0f, x, y, color.toFloatBits(), duration, null);
2764    }
2765
2766    /**
2767     * Changes the background at position x,y so it becomes the given encodedColor, taking duration seconds. The
2768     * background will keep the changed color after the effect, unless drawn over.
2769     * <br>
2770     * This will only behave correctly if you call {@link Stage#act()} before you call {@link Stage#draw()}, but after
2771     * any changes to the contents of this SparseLayers. If you change the contents, then draw, and then act, that will
2772     * draw the contents without the recolor this applies, then apply the recolor when you call act(), then quickly
2773     * overwrite the recolor in the next frame. That visually appears as nothing happening other than a delay.
2774     * @param x the x-coordinate of the cell to recolor
2775     * @param y the y-coordinate of the cell to recolor
2776     * @param encodedColor what to gradually change the cell's color to, as a packed float
2777     * @param duration how long the total transition should take in seconds
2778     */
2779    public void recolor(final int x, final int y, final float encodedColor, float duration) {
2780        recolor(0f, x, y, encodedColor, duration, null);
2781    }
2782
2783    /**
2784     * Changes the background at position x,y so it becomes the given encodedColor, waiting for {@code delay} (in
2785     * seconds) before performing it, taking duration seconds. The background will keep the changed color after
2786     * the effect, unless drawn over.
2787     * <br>
2788     * This will only behave correctly if you call {@link Stage#act()} before you call {@link Stage#draw()}, but after
2789     * any changes to the contents of this SparseLayers. If you change the contents, then draw, and then act, that will
2790     * draw the contents without the recolor this applies, then apply the recolor when you call act(), then quickly
2791     * overwrite the recolor in the next frame. That visually appears as nothing happening other than a delay.
2792     * @param delay how long to wait in seconds before starting the effect
2793     * @param x the x-coordinate of the cell to recolor
2794     * @param y the y-coordinate of the cell to recolor
2795     * @param encodedColor what to gradually change the cell's color to, as a packed float
2796     * @param duration how long the total transition should take in seconds
2797     */
2798    public void recolor(final float delay, final int x, final int y, final float encodedColor, float duration) {
2799        recolor(delay, x, y, encodedColor, duration, null);
2800    }
2801    /**
2802     * Changes the background at position x,y so it becomes the given encodedColor, waiting for {@code delay} (in
2803     * seconds) before performing it, taking duration seconds. The background will keep the changed color after the
2804     * effect, unless drawn over. Additionally, enqueue {@code postRunnable} for running after the created action ends.
2805     * <br>
2806     * This will only behave correctly if you call {@link Stage#act()} before you call {@link Stage#draw()}, but after
2807     * any changes to the contents of this SparseLayers. If you change the contents, then draw, and then act, that will
2808     * draw the contents without the recolor this applies, then apply the recolor when you call act(), then quickly
2809     * overwrite the recolor in the next frame. That visually appears as nothing happening other than a delay.
2810     * @param delay how long to wait in seconds before starting the effect
2811     * @param x the x-coordinate of the cell to recolor
2812     * @param y the y-coordinate of the cell to recolor
2813     * @param encodedColor what to gradually change the cell's color to, as a packed float
2814     * @param duration how long the total transition should take in seconds
2815     * @param postRunnable a Runnable to execute after the recolor completes; may be null to do nothing.
2816     */
2817    public void recolor(final float delay, final int x, final int y, final float encodedColor, float duration,
2818            /* @Nullable */ Runnable postRunnable) {
2819        if(x < 0 || x >= gridWidth || y < 0 || y >= gridHeight)
2820            return;
2821        duration = Math.max(0.015f, duration);
2822        final float ac = backgrounds[x][y];
2823        final int nbActions = 2 + (0 < delay ? 1 : 0) + (postRunnable == null ? 0 : 1);
2824        final Action[] sequence = new Action[nbActions];
2825        int index = 0;
2826        if (0 < delay)
2827            sequence[index++] = Actions.delay(delay);
2828        sequence[index++] = new TemporalAction(duration) {
2829            @Override
2830            protected void update(float percent) {
2831                backgrounds[x][y] = SColor.lerpFloatColors(ac, encodedColor, percent);
2832            }
2833        };
2834        if(postRunnable != null)
2835        {
2836            sequence[index++] = Actions.run(postRunnable);
2837        }
2838        /* Do this one last, so that hasActiveAnimations() returns true during 'postRunnables' */
2839        sequence[index] = Actions.delay(duration, Actions.run(new Runnable() {
2840            @Override
2841            public void run() {
2842                backgrounds[x][y] = encodedColor;
2843            }
2844        }));
2845
2846        addAction(Actions.sequence(sequence));
2847    }
2848
2849
2850
2851
2852    /**
2853     * Changes the foreground in the given layer at position x,y so it becomes the given color, taking duration
2854     * seconds. The foreground color will keep the changed color after the effect, unless drawn over.
2855     * <br>
2856     * This will only behave correctly if you call {@link Stage#act()} before you call {@link Stage#draw()}, but after
2857     * any changes to the contents of this SparseLayers. If you change the contents, then draw, and then act, that will
2858     * draw the contents without the recolor this applies, then apply the recolor when you call act(), then quickly
2859     * overwrite the recolor in the next frame. That visually appears as nothing happening other than a delay.
2860     * @param x the x-coordinate of the cell to recolor
2861     * @param y the y-coordinate of the cell to recolor
2862     * @param layer which layer to affect; if you haven't specified a layer when placing text, then this should be 0
2863     * @param color what to gradually change the cell's color to, as a Color object
2864     * @param duration how long the total transition should take in seconds
2865     */
2866    public void recolor(final int x, final int y, final int layer, final Color color, float duration) {
2867        recolor(0f, x, y, layer, color.toFloatBits(), duration, null);
2868    }
2869    /**
2870     * Changes the foreground in the given layer at position x,y so it becomes the given encodedColor, taking duration
2871     * seconds. The foreground color will keep the changed color after the effect, unless drawn over.
2872     * <br>
2873     * This will only behave correctly if you call {@link Stage#act()} before you call {@link Stage#draw()}, but after
2874     * any changes to the contents of this SparseLayers. If you change the contents, then draw, and then act, that will
2875     * draw the contents without the recolor this applies, then apply the recolor when you call act(), then quickly
2876     * overwrite the recolor in the next frame. That visually appears as nothing happening other than a delay.
2877     * @param x the x-coordinate of the cell to recolor
2878     * @param y the y-coordinate of the cell to recolor
2879     * @param layer which layer to affect; if you haven't specified a layer when placing text, then this should be 0
